titleStmt.title: The Honest Man's Fortune1613
titleStmt.author: Field, Nathan; Massinger, Philip; Fletcher, John

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima:
div.stage: Enter the Duke of Orleans, and the Earl of Amiens at several doors.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.p: Morrow my lord of Orleans.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You salute me like a stranger; brother Orleans were to me a title more belonging, whom you call the husband of your sister.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Would the circumstances of your brotherhood had never offered cause to make our conversation less familiar: I meet you like a hindrance in your way: your great law suit is now upon the tongue, and ready for a judgement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Came you from the hall now?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Without stay; the court is full, and such a press of people does attend the issue, as if some great man were brought to his arraignment.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Every mother's son of all that multitude of hearers went to be a witness of the misery your sister's fortunes must have come to, if my adversary who did love her first, had been her husband.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: The success may draw a testimony from them to confirm the same opinion, but they went prepared with no such hope or purpose.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And did you entreat, the number of them that are come with no such hope or purpose.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Tush, your own experience of my heart can answer ye.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: This doubtful, makes me clearly understand your disposition.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: If your cause be just,
I wish you a conclusion like your cause.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I can have any common charity to such a prayer
From a friend I would expect a love to prosper in;
Without exceptions such a love as might
Make all my under takings thankful to't;
Precisely just is seldom faithful in our wishes
To another man's desires: farewell. Exit Orl.

div.stage: Enter Montague having a purse, Duboys, Longueville, and Voramer the page with two gaskets.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Here comes your adversaries brother in law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The lord of Amiens.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: From the hall I think.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I did so: save your lordship.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's a wish my lord, as courteous to my present state,
As ever honest mind was thankful for;
For now my safety must expose itself
To question: yet to look for any free
Or hearty salutation (Sir from you)
Would be unreasonable in me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your sister is my adversaries wife;
That nearness needs must consequently draw
Your inclination to him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I will grant
Him all the nearness his alliance claims,
And yet be nothing less impartial
My lord of Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lord of Montague yet:
But (Sir) how long the dignity or state
Belonging to it will continue, stands
Upon the dangerous passage of this hour,
Either for ever more to be confirmed,
Or like the time wherein 'twas pleaded, gone:
Gone with it, never to be called again.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Justice direct your process to the end;
To both your persons my respect shall still
Be equal; but the righteous cause is that
Which bears my wishes to the side it holds,
Wherever may it prosper. Exit Amiens.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then my thanks
Are proper to you, if a man may raise
A confidence upon a lawful ground
I have no reason to be once perplexed
With any doubtful motion, Longueville,
That lord of Amiens, (Didst observe him?) has
A worthy nature in him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Either 'tis his nature or his cunning.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's the vizard of most men's actions,
Whose dissembled lives
Do carry only the similitude
Of goodness on 'em, but for him
Honest behaviour makes a true report,
What disposition does inhabit him,
Essential virtue.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Then 'tis pity that
Injurious Orleans is his brother.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: He is but his brother in law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: La? that's as bad.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How is your law as bad? I rather wish
The hangman thy executor then that
Equivocation should be ominous.

div.stage: Enter two lawyers, and two creditors.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Some of your lawyers. —

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: What is ominous?

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: Let no distrust trouble your lordship's thought.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: The evidences of your questioned land
Have not much as any literal
Advantage in 'em to be made against
Your title.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: And your council understands
The business fully.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: They're industrious, just.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: And very confident.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: Your state endures
A voluntary trial; like a man
Whose honours are maliciously accused.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: The accusation serves to clear his cause.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: And to approve his truth more.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: So shall all
Your adversaries pleadings strengthen your
Possession.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: And be set upon record
To witness the hereditary right
Of you and yours.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: Courage, you have the law.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And you the profits.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If discouragement
Could work upon me, your assurances
Would put me strongly into heart again;
But I was never fearful: and let fate
Deceive my expectation, yet I am
Prepared against dejection.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: So are we.

sp.speaker: 2 creditor
sp.l: We have received a comfortable hope
That all will speed well.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What is he Duboys?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: A creditor.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I thought so, for he speaks
As if he were a partner in his state.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir, I am largely indebted to your loves.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: More to their purses.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Which you shall not lose.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: Your lordship.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: That's another creditor.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: Has interest in me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have more of him.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: And I have had so many promises
From these and all your learned councillors,
How certainly your cause will prosper: that —

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You brought no sergeants with you?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: To attend his ill success.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good sir, I will not be
Unthankful either to their industries
Or your affections.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: All your land (My lord)
Is at the bar now, give me but ten crowns
I'll save you harmless.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Take him at his word;
If he does lose, you're saved by miracle,
For I never knew a lawyer yet undone.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: Then now you shall sir, if this prospers not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you do not force your voice
To such a loudness, but be thrifty now;
Preserve it till you come to plead at bar
It will be much more profitable in
The satisfaction then the promise.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: Is not this a satisfaction to engage
Myself for this assurance, if he —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No sir, my ruin never shall import
Another's loss, if not by accident,
And that my purpose is not guilty of:
You are engaged in nothing but your care. Exit law.
Attend the procurator to the court,
Observe how things incline, and bring me word.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I dare not sir; if I be taken there,
Mine ears will be in danger.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why? hast thou
Committed something that deserves thine ears?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, but I fear the noise; my hearing will be
Perished by the noise; 'tis as good 't want
A member, as to lose the use —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: The ornament is excepted.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Well my lord
I'll put 'em to the hazard. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: Your desires be prosperous to you.

sp.speaker: 2 creditor
sp.l: Our best prayers wait
Upon your fortune. Exeunt Cred.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: For yourselves, not him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou canst not blame 'em: I am in their debts.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But had your large expense (A part whereof
You owe 'em) for unprofitable silks
And laces, been bestowed among the poor,
That would have prayed the right way for you:
Not upon you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: For unprofitable silks
And laces? now believe me honest boy
Thou'st hit upon a reprehension that belongs
Unto me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: By — my lord,
I had not so unmannerly a thought,
To reprehend you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why I love thee for't.
Mine own acknowledgement confirms thy words:
For once I do remember, coming from
The mercers, where my purse had spent itself
On those unprofitable toys thou speakst of,
A man half naked with his poverty
Did meet me, and requested my relief:
I wanted whence to give it, yet his eyes
Spoke for him, those I could have satisfied
With some unfruitful sorrow, (If my tears
Would not have added rather to his grief,
Then eased it) but the true compassion that
I should have given I had not: this began
To make me think how many such men's wants
The vain superfluous cost I wore upon
My outside would have clothed, and left myself
A habit as becoming: to increase
This new consideration there came one
Clad in a garment plain and thrifty, yet
As decent as these fair dear follies; made
As if it were of purpose to despise
The vanity of show: his purse had still
The power to do a charitable deed,
And did it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Yet your inclination, sir,
Deserved no less to be commended, than his action.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Prithee do not flatter me;
He that intends well, yet deprives himself
Of means to put his good thoughts into deed,
Deceives his purpose of the due reward
That goodness merits: oh antiquity
Thy great examples of nobility
Are out of imitation, or at least
So lamely followed, that thou art as much
Before this age in virtue, as in time.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Sir, it must needs be lamely followed, when
The chiefest men love to follow it
Are for the most part cripples.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Soldiers, my lord, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Tis true duboys: but if the law disables me no more
For noble actions, then good purposes,
I'll practise how to exercise the worth
Commended to us by our ancestors;
The poor neglected soldier shall command
Me from a lady's courtship, and the form
I'll study shall no more be taught me by
The tailor, but the scholar; that expense
Which hitherto has been to entertain
Th' intemperate pride and pleasure of the taste
Shall fill my table more to satisfy,
And less to surfeit.
What an honest work it would be; when we find
A virgin in her poverty, and youth
Inclining to be tempted, to employ
As much persuasion, and as much expense
To keep her upright as men use to do upon her falling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: 'Tis charity that many maids will be unthankful for,
And some will rather take it for a wrong,
To buy 'em out of their inheritance,
The thing that they were born to.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Longueville thou bringst a cheerful promise in thy face.
There stands no pale report upon thy cheek,
To give me fear or knowledge of my loss, 'tis red and lively.
How proceeds my suit?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: That's with labour sir, a labour that to those of Hercules
May add another; or (At least) be called
A imitation of this burning shirt:
For 'twas a pain of that unmerciful
Perplexity, to shoulder through the throng
Of people that attended your success:
My sweaty linen fixed upon my skin,
Still as they pulled me, took that with it; 'twas
A fear I should have left my flesh among 'em:
Yet I was patient, for ( methought ) the toil
Might be an emblem of the difficult
And weary passage to get out of law.
And to make up the dear similitude,
When I was forth seeking my handkercher
To wipe my sweat off, I did find a cause
To make me sweat more, for my purse was lost
Among their finger.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: There 'twas rather found.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: By them.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I mean so.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Well, I will restore
Thy damage to thee: how proceeds my suit?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.l: Like one at brokers; I think forfeited.
Your promising council at the first
Put strongly forward with a laboured speed,
And such a violence of pleading, that
His fee in sugar-candy scarce will make
His throat a satisfaction for the hurt
He did it, and he carried the whole cause
Before him with so clear a passage, that
The people in the favour of your side
Cried Montague, Montague: in the spite of him
That cried out silence, and began to laugh
Your adversaries advocate to scorn:
Who like a cunning footman? set me forth
With such a temperate easy kind of course
To put him into exercise of strength,
And followed his advantages so close,
That when your hot mouthed pleader thought 'Had won,
Before he reached it, he was out of breath,
And then the other stripped him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So all is lost.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But how I know not; for ( methought ) I stood
Confounded with the clamour of the court,
Like one embarked upon a storm at sea,
Where the tempestuous noise of thunder mixed
With roaring of the billows, and the thick
Imperfect language of the seamen, takes
His understanding and his safety both
Together from him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou dost bring ill news

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Of what I was unwilling to have been
The first reporter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Didst observe no more?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: At least no better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then th' art not informed
So well as I am; I can tell thee that
Will please thee, for when all else left my cause,
My very adversaries took my part.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: — whosoever told you that abused you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Credit me, he took my part
When all forsook me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Took it from you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes I mean so, and I think he had just cause
To take it when the verdict gave it him.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: His spirit would ha' sunk him, ere he could
Have carried an ill fortune of this weight so lightly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nothing is a misery unless our weakness apprehend it so;
We cannot be more faithful to ourselves
In any thing that's manly, than to make
Ill fortune as contemptible to us
As it makes us to others.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Here come they
Whose very countenances will tell you how
Contemptible it is to others.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The sir of knighthood may be given him, ere
They hear you now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good sir but a word.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How soon the loss of wealth makes any man
Grow out of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let me see I pray sir,
Never stood you upon the pillory?

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: The pillory?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O now I know you did not.
You've ears, I thought ye had lost 'em; pray observe,
Here's one that once was gracious in our eyes.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: O my lord, have an eye upon him.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But ha' you ne'er a counsel to redeem
His land yet from the judgement?

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: None but this, a writ of error to remove the cause.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No more of error, we have been in that too much already.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.p: If you will reverse the judgement, you must trust to that delay.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Delay? Indeed he's like to trust to that,
With you has any dealing.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.p: Ere the law proceeds to an habere facias possessionem.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: That's a language sir, I understand not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Thou'rt a very strange unthankful fellow to have taken fees of such a liberal measure, and then give a man hard words for's money.

sp.speaker: 1 lawyer
sp.l: If men will hazard their salvations,
What should I say? I've other business.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You're ith' right;
That's it you should say now prosperity has left me.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: Have an eye upon him; if
We lose him now, he's gone for ever; stay
And dog him: I'll go fetch the officers.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Dog him you bloodhound: by this point thou shalt more safely dog an angry lion then attempt him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Do but steer to fetch a sergeant; and (Besides your loss
Of labour) I'll have you beaten, till
Those casements in your faces be false lights.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Falser than those you sell by.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who gave you commission to abuse my friends thus?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Sir, are those your friends that would betray you?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Tis to save themselves rather then betray me.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: Your lordship makes a just construction of it.

sp.speaker: 2 creditor
sp.l: All our desire is but to get our own.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Your wife's desires and yours do differ then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So far as my ability will go
You shall have satisfaction Longeville,

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And leave yourself neglected; every man
Is first a debtor to his own demands, being honest.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: As I take it sir, I did
Not entertain you for my counsellor.

sp.speaker: Ilong.
sp.l: Counsels the office of a servant,
When the master falls upon a danger: as
Defence is never threaten with your eyes,
They are no cockatrices; do you hear?
Talk with a girdler, or a milner,
He can inform you of a kind of men
That first undid the profit of those trades
By bringing up the form of carrying
There morglachs in their hands: with some of those
A man may make himself a privilege
To ask a question at the prison gates,
Without your good permission.

sp.speaker: 2 creditor
sp.l: By your leave.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stay sir, what one example since the time
That first you put your hat off to me, have
You noted in me to encourage you
To this presumption? by the justice now
Of thine own rule, I should begin with thee,
I should turn thee away ungratified
For all thy former kindness, forget
Thou ever didst me any service: 'tis not fear
Of being arrested makes me thus incline
To satisfy you; for you see by him,
I lost not all defences with my state;
The curses of a man to whom I am
Beholding terrify me more, than all
The violence he can pursue me with.
Duboys, I did prepare me for the worst;
These two small cabinets do comprehend
The sum of all the wealth that it hath pleased
Adversity to leave me, one as rich
As th' other, both in jewels; take thou this,
And as the order put within it shall
Direct thee, distribute it half between
Those creditors, and th' other half among
My servants: for (Sir) they are my creditors
As well as you are, they have trusted me
With their advancement: if the value fail,
To please you all, my first increase of means
Shall offer you a fuller payment; be content
To leave me something, and imagine that
You put a new beginner into credit.

sp.speaker: Creditor
sp.p: So prosper our own blessings, as we wish you to your merit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Are your silences of discontent, or of sorrow?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Sir, we would not leave you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Do but suffer us to follow you, and what our present means, or industries hereafter can provide, shall serve you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O desire me not to live
To such a baseness, as to be maintained
By those that serve me; pray be gone, I will
Defend your honesties to any man
That shall report you have forsaken me;
I pray be gone. Exeunt servants and crediers.
Why dost thou weep my boy,
Because I do not bid thee go too?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No, I weep (My lord) because I would not go;
I fear you will command me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No my child,
I will not; that would discommend th'intent
Of all my other actions: thou art yet
Unable to advise thyself a course,
Should I put thee to seek it; after that
I must excuse or at the least forgive
Any uncharitable deed that can be done against myself.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Every day (My lord) I tarry with you, I'll account
A day of blessing to me; for I shall
Have so much less time left me of my life
When I am from you: and if misery
Befall you (Which I hope so good a man
Was never born to) I will take my part,
And make my willingness increase my strength
To bear it. In the winter I will spare
Mine own clothes from myself to cover you;
And in the summer, carry some of yours
To ease you: I'll do any thing I can.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why, thou art able to make misery
Ashamed of hurting, when thy weakness can
Both bear it, and despise it: come my boy
I will provide some better way for thee
Then this thou speakst of; 'tis the comfort that
Ill fortune has undone me into the fashion:
For now in this age most men do begin,
To keep but one boy, that kept many men. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Orleans, a servant, his lady following.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Where is she? call her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your friend sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What friend, good my lord?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your Montague, madam, he will shortly want
Those courtly graces that you love him for;
The means wherewith he purchased this, and this,
And all his own provisions to the least
Proportion of his feeding or his clothes,
Came out of that inheritance of land
Which he unjustly lived on: but the law
Has given me right in't, and possession; now
Thou shalt perceive his bravery vanish, as
This jewel does from thee now, and these pearls
To him that owes 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ye are the owner sir of every thing that does belong to me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: No, not of him, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O good God!

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: But in a while your mind will change, and be
As ready to disclaim him; when his wants
And miseries have perished his good face,
And taken off the sweetness that has made
Him pleasing in a woman's understanding.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O heaven, how gracious had creation been
To women, who are born without defence,
If to our hearts there had been doors through which
Or husbands might have looked into our thoughts,
And made themselves undoubtful.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Made 'em mad.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: With honest women.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thou dost still pretend
A title to that virtue: prithee let
Thy honesty speak freely to me now.
Thou knowest that Montaigue of whose land
I am the master, did affect three first,
And should have had thee, if the strength of friends
Had not prevailed above thine own consent.
I have undone him; tell me how thou dost
Consider his ill fortune and my good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll tell you justly his undoing is
An argument for pity? and for tears
In all their dispositions that have known
The honour and the goodness of his life:
Yet that addition of prosperity,
Which you have got by't, no indifferent man
Will malice or repine at, if the law
Be not abused in 't; howsoever since
You have the upper fortune of him, 'twill
Be some dishonour to you to bear yourself
With any pride or glory over him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: This may be truly spoken, but in thee
It is not honest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes, so honest, that I care not if the chaste Penelope
Were now alive to hear me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Who comes there?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Save ye.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Now sir, you have heard of prosperous Montague.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No sir, I have heard of Montague,
But of your prosperity.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is he distracted.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He does bear his loss with such a noble strength
Of patience that,
Had fortune eyes to see him, she would weep
For having hurt him, and pretending that
She did it but for trial of his worth:
Hereafter ever love him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I perceive you love him, and because (I must confess)
He does deserve that though for some respects,
I have not given him that acknowledgement,
Yet in mine honour I did still conclude to use him nobly.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, that will become your reputation and make me grow proud of your alliance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I did reserve the doing of this friendship till I had
His fortunes at my mercy, that the world
May tell him 'tis a willing courtesy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This change will make me happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: 'Tis a change; thou shalt behold it, then observe me when
That Montague had possession of my land,
I was his rival, and at last obtained
This lady who by promise of her own
Affection to him, should ha' been his wife;
I had her, and withheld her like a pawn,
Till now my land is rendered to me again,
And since it is so, you shall see I have
The conscience not to keep her — give him her — draws
For by the faithful temper of my sword, she shall not tarry with me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Give me way —Draws.
Thou most unworthy man — give me way
Or by the wrong he does the innocent,
I'll end thy misery and his wickedness, together.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Stay and let me justify
My husband in that, I have wronged his bed
sp.stage: Enter Amiens in amazement, the servants following him.
sp.l: Never — all shames that can afflict me fall
Upon me if I ever wronged you;

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Didst thou not confess it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Twas to save your blood from shedding, that has
Turned my brother's edge;
He that beholds our thoughts as plainly as
Our faces, knows it, I did never hurt
My honesty but by accusing it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Women's consents are sooner credited
Then their denials: and I'll never trust
Her body that prefers any defence
Before the safety of her honour — here —Enter servant
Show forth that stranger — give me not a word
Thou seest a danger ready to be tempted.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Cast that upon me rather than my shame,
And as I am now dying I will now —
That I am honest.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Put her out of doors; but that I fear my land
May go again to Montague, I would kill thee, I am loath,
To make a beggar of him that way; or else —
Go now you have the liberty of flesh,
And you may put it to a double use,
One for your pleasure, th'other to maintain
Your well-beloved, he will want. Exit lady
In such a charitable exercise
The virtue will excuse you for the vice. Exit Orleans.

div.stage: Enter Amiens drawn, Montague, Vercamor meeting.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What means your lordship?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: For the love of God —

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thou hast advantage of me, cast away this buckler.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So he is sir, for he lives
With one that is undone — a void us boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I'll first avoid my safety,
Your rapier shall be buttoned, with my head before it touch my master.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Montague?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know my sister?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: For a whore?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You lie, and shall lie lower if you dare abuse her honour.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am honest.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Honest!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Upon my faith I am.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What did then persuade thee to condemn thyself?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your safety.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I had rather be exposed
To danger, than dishonour; thou'st betrayed
The reputation of my family
More basely by the falseness of that word,
Then that thou hast delivered me asleep
Into the hands of base enemy.
Relief will never make thee sensible
Of thy disgraces; let thy wants compel thee to it.Exit

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O I am a miserable woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why madam? are you utterly without means to relieve you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I have nothing sir, unless by changing of these clothes for worse, and then at last the worst for nakedness.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stand off boy, nakedness would be a change
To please us madam, to delight us both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What nakedness sir?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why the nakedness of body madam, we were lovers once.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Never dishonest lovers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Honesty has no allowance now to give ourselves.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor you allowance against honesty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I'll send my boy hence, opportunity
Shall be our servant, come and meet me first
With kisses like a stranger at the door,
And then invite me nearer to receive
A more familiar inward welcome — where,
Instead of tapers made of virgin's wax
Th'increasing flames of our desires shall light
Us to a banquet: and before the taste
Be dull with satisfaction, I'll prepare
A nourishment composed of every thing
That bears a natural friendship to the blood,
And that shall set another edge upon't,
Or else between the courses of the feast
We'll dally out an exercise of time,
That ever as one appetite expires another may succeed it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O my lord, how has your nature lost her worthiness?
When our affections had their liberty,
Or kisses met as temperately as
The hands of sisters, or of brothers, that
Our bloods were then as moving; than you were
So noble, that I durst have trusted your
Embraces in an opportunity
Silent enough to serve a ravisher,
And yet come from you — undishonoured — how
You think me altered, that you promise your
Attempt success I know not; but were all
The sweet temptations that deceive us set
On this side, and one that side all the waiters,
These neither should persuade me nor the force.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then misery may waste your body.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, but lust shall never.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I have found you still as uncorrupted as I left you first
Continue so; and I will serve you with
As much devotion as my word, my hand
Or purse can show you; and to justify
That promise, here is half the wealth I have,
Take it, you owe me nothing, till you fall
From virtue, which the better to protect
I have bethought me of a present means
Give me the letter; this commends my boy
Into the service of a lady, whose
Free goodness you have been acquainted with Lamira.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir I know her.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then believe her entertainment will be noble to you;
My boy shall bring you thither: and relate
Your manner of misfortune if your own
Report needs any witness: so I kiss your hand good lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how to promise, but I cannot be unthankful.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: All that you can implore in thankfulness
Be yours, to make you the more prosperous.
Farewell my boy, — I am not yet oppressed. Exit lady vera.
Having the power to help one that's distressed.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What shall we do now: swords are out of use,
And words are out of credit.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: We must serve.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The means to get a service will first spend
Our purses; and except we can allow
Ourselves an entertainment, service will
Neglect us; now 'tis grown into a doubt
Whether the Mr. or the servant gives the countenance.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Then fall in with mistresses.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: They keep more servants now (Indeed) than men,
But yet the age is grown so populous
Of those attendants, that the women are
Grown full to.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: What shall we propound ourselves?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'll think on't.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Do; old occupations have too many setters up to prosper, some uncommon trade would thrive now.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We'll e'en make up some half a dozen proper men,
And should not we get more
Than all your female sinners?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: If the house be seated as it should be privately.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I but that would make a multitude of witches.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Witches? how prithee?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thus the bands would all turn witches to revenge
Themselves upon; us and the women that
Come to us, for disguises must wear beards,
And that's they say, a token of a witch.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: What shall we then do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We must study on't,
With more consideration; stay Duboyes
Are not the lord of Orleans and the lord
Of Amiens enemies?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Yes, what of that.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Methinks the factions of two such great men.
Should give a promise of advancement now
To us that want it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Let the plot be thine, and in the enterprise I'll second thee.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I have it, we will first set down ourselves
The method of a quarrel; and make choice
Of some frequented tavern; or such a place
Of common notice to perform it in
By way of undertaking to maintain
The several honours of those enemies.
Thou for the lord of Orleanes; I for Amiens.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I like the project, and I think 'twill take
The better, since their difference first did rise
From his occasion whom we followed once.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We cannot hope less after the report,
Than entertainment or gratuity,
Yet those are ends, I do not aim at most;
Greater spirits that are needy, and will thrive,
Must labour whiles such troubles are alive.Exeunt

sp.speaker: La p.
sp.p: Slander is sharper than the sword. I have fed this three days upon leaf tobacco, for want of other victuals.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You have lived the honester captain; but be not so dejected, but hold up thy head, and meat will sooner fall i'thy mouth.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I care not so much for meat, so I had but good liquor, for which my guts croak like so many frogs for rain.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: It seems, you are troubled with the wind-colic captain, swallow a bullet: 'tis present remedy I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: A bullet; if you be captain, my paunch is nothing but a pile of bullets; when I was in any service I stood between my general and the shot, like a mudwall; I am all lead, from the crown of the head to the sole of the foot, not a sound bone about me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: It seems you have been in terrible hot service captain.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: It has ever been the fate of the low country wars to spoil many a man, I ha' not been the first nor shall not be the last: but I'll tell you sir, (Hunger has brought it in to mind) I served once at the siege of Brest 'tis memorable to this day, where we were in great distress for victuals, whole troops fainted more for want of food then for blood, and died, yet we were resolved to stand it out; I myself was but then gentleman of a company, and had as much need as any man, and indeed I had perished had not a miraculous providence preserved me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: As how good captain?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Marry sir e'en as I was fainting and falling down for want of sustenance, the enemy made a shot at me, and struck me full ith' paunch with a penny loaf.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Instead of a bullet!

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: In stead of a bullet.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: That was miraculous in deed; and that loaf sustained you.

sp.speaker: Lap-p.
sp.p: Nourished me or I had famished with the rest.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You have done worthy acts being a soldier, and now you shall give me leave to requite your tale, and to acquaint you with the most notorious deeds that I have done being a courtier. I protest captain I will lie no more than you have done.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I can endure no lies.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I know you cannot captain, therefore I'll only tell you of strange things, I did once a deed of charity for itself; I assisted a poor widow in a suit, and obtained it, yet I protest I took not a penny for my labour.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: 'Tis no such strange thing.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: By Mars captain, but it is, and a very strange thing too in a courtier, it may take the upper hand of your penny loaf for a miracle. I could ha' told you how many ladies have languished for my love, and how I was once solicited by the mother, the daughter, and grandmother out of the least of which I might have digged myself a fortune; they were all great ladies, for two of them were so big I could hardly embrace them: but I was sluggish in my rising courses, and therefore let them pass; what means I had is spent upon such as had the wit to cheat me; that wealth being gone, I have only bought experience with it, with a strong hope to cheat others; but see here comes the much declined Montague, who had all the man or houses, which were the body of his estate overthrown by a great wind.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: How by a great wind? was he not over thrown by law?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes, marry was he: but there was terrible puffing and blowing before he was overthrown, if you observed, and believe it captain, there's no wind so dangerous to a building as a lawyer's breath.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: What's he with him?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: An eminent citizen. Monsieur Mallicorne, let's stand aside and listen their design.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir, profit is the crown of labour, it is the life, the soul of the industrious merchant, in it he makes his paradise, and for it neglects wife, children, friends, parents, nay all the world, and delivers up himself to the violence of storms, and to be tossed into unknown airs; as there is no faculty so perilous, so there's none so worthy profitable.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Sir, I am very well possessed of it, and what of my poor fortunes remains, I would gladly hazard upon the sea; it cannot deal worse with me then the land, though it sink or throw it in the hands of pirates. I have yet five hundred pounds left, and your honest and worthy acquaintance may make me a young merchant; th'one moiety of what I have I would gladly adventure.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How adventure? you shall hazard nothing: you shall only join with me in certain commodities that are safe arrived unto the key; you shall neither be in doubt of danger nor damage; but so much money disbursed, so much receive; sir I would have you conceive I pursue it not for any good your money will do me, but merely out of mine own freeness and courtesy to pleasure you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I can believe no less, and you express a noble nature, seeking to build up a man so ruined as myself.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Captain here is subject for us to work upon if we have wit; you hear that there is money yet left, and it is going to be laid out in rattles, bells, hobby-horses, brown paper, or some such like sale commodities; now it would do better in our purses, upon our backs in good goldlace, and scarlet, and then we might pursue our projects, and our devices towards my lady Annabella; go to, there's a conceit newly landed; hark I stand in good reputation with him, and therefore may the better cheat him: captain, take a few instructions from me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What moneys I have is at your disposing, and upon twelve I will meet you at the palace with it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I will there expect you, and so I take my leave.Exit

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You apprehend me?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Why do ye think I am a dunce?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Not a dunce captain, but you might give me leave to misdoubt that pregnancy in a soldier, which is proper and hereditary to a courtier; but prosecute it, I will both second, and give credit to it. Good monsieur Montague, I would your whole revenues lay within the circuit of mine arms, that I might as easily bestow, or restore it unto you as my courtesy.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: My zealous wishes sir, do accompany his for your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Believe it sir, our affection towards you is a strong band of friendship.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: To which I shall most willingly seal. But believe me gentlemen in a broken estate, the bond of friendship oft is forfeited, but that it is your free and ingenuous nature to renew it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sir, I will amply extend myself to your use, and am very zealously afflicted as not one of your least friends for your croocked fate; but let it seize you with any dejection, you have as I hear a sufficient competency left, which well disposed may erect you as high in the world's account as ever.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I cannot live to hope it, much less enjoy it, nor
is it any part of my endeavour; my study is to render every man his own, and to contain myself within the limits of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I have the grant of an office given me by some noble favourites of mine in court, there stands but a small matter between me and it, if your ability be such to lay down the present sum, out of the love I bear you, before any other man, it shall be confirmed yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I have heard you often speak of such a thing; if it be assured to you I will gladly deal in it that portion I have, I would not hazard upon one course, for I see the most certainest is incertain.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Having money sir, you could not light upon men that could give better direction; there is at this time a friend of mine upon the seas; to be plain with you, he is a pirate, that hath written to me to work his freedom, and by this gentleman's means, whose acquaintance is not small at court; we have the word of a worthy man for it, only there is some money to be suddenly disbursed, and if your happiness be such to make it up you shall receive treble gain by it, and good assurance for it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Gentlemen out of the weakness of my estate you seem (To have some knowledge of my breast) that wood if it were possible advance my declined fortunes, to satisfy all men of whom I have had credit, and I know no way better than these which you propose; I have some money ready under my command, some part of it is already promised, but the remainder is yours to such uses as are propounded.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Appoint some certain place of meeting, for these affairs requires expedition.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I will make it my present business: at twelve, I am to meet Mallicorne the merchant at the palace, you know him sir, about some negotiation of the same nature, there I will be ready to tender you that money, upon such conditions as we shall conclude off.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: The care of it be yours, so much as they affair concerns you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Your caution is effectual, and till then I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Good Mr. Montague. Exit

div.stage: Within a elamor, down with their weapons. Enter Longavile and Dubois, their swords drawn, servants and others between them.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Nay gentlemen what mean you pray be quiet, have some respect unto the house.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A treacherous slave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Thou dost revile thyself base Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I say thou art a villain and a corrupt one, that hast some seven years fed on thy master's trencher, yet never bredst good blood towards him: for if, thou hadst have a sounder heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: So sir, you can use your tongue something nimbler than your sword.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Wood you could use your tongue well of your master, friend you might have better employment for your sword.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I say again and I will speak it loud and often, that Orleans is a noble gentleman with whom Amiens is to light to poise the scale.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: He is the weaker for taking of a praise out of thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: This hand shall seal his merit at thy heart.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Part them my masters part them.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Part them sir, why do you not part them, you stand by with your sword in your hand, and cry part 'em.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why you must know my friend my clothes are better than yours, and in a good suit, I do never use to part anybody .

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And it is discretion.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I marry is it captain.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Duboies though this place privilege thee, know where next we meet, the blood which at thy heart flows drops at thy feet.

div.stage: Enter Amience in haste, his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would not spend it better than in this quarrel, and on such a hazard.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: What uproars this, must my name here be questioned in tavern brawls, and by affected ruffians?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Not we indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Fear cannot make me shrink out of your fury, though you were greater than your name doth make you, I am one, and the opposer; if your swollen rage have ought in malice to enforce express it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I seek thee not nor shalt thou ever gain
That credit, which a blow from me wood give thee,
By my — I more detest that fellow
Which took my part then thee, that he durst offer
To take my honour in his feeble arms,
And spend it in a drinking room; which way went he?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: That way sir, I wood you wood after for I do fear we shall have some more scuffling.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I'll follow him, and if my speed o'er take him,
I shall ill thank him for his forwardness. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I am glad he's gone, for I do not love to see a sword drawn in the hand of a man that looks so furious, there's no jesting with edge tools, how say you captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I say 'tis better jesting then to be in earnest with them. Enter Orleance.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: How now? what's the difference? they say there have been swords drawn, and in my quarrel, let me know that man, whose love is so sincere to spend his blood for my sake, I will bounteously requite him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: We were all of your side, but there he stands begun it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Duboyes?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, thou hast received no hurt?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Not any, nor wear this body stuck full of wounds, I should not count them hurts, being taken in so honourable a cause as the defence of my most worthy lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: The dedication of thy love to me requires my ample bounty, thou art mine, for I do find thee made unto my purposes. Monsieur Laverdine, pardon my neglect I not observed you, and how runs rumour.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, it runs my lord like a foot man without a cloak, to show that what's once rumoured it cannot be hid.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And what say the rabble, am not I the subject of their talk?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Troth my lord the common mouth speaks foul words.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Of me, for turning away thy wife do they not?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Faith the men do a little murmur at it and say, 'tis an ill precedent in so great a man, marry the women they rail, out right.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Out upon them rampallions I'll keep myself safe enough out of their fingers, but what say my pretty
jelly composed gallant that censure every thing more desperate than it is dangerous; what say they?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Marry they are laying wagers, what death you shall die; one offers to lay five hundred pounds; and yet he had but a groat about him, and that was in two twopence too to any man that would make it up a shilling; that you were killed with a pistol charged with white powder; another offered to pawn his soul for five shillings, and yet nobody would take him, that you were stabbed to death and should die with more wounds than Cesar.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And who should be the butchers that should do it? Montague and his associates?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: So 'tis conjectured.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And believe it, sweet prince, it is to be feared, and therefore prevented.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: By turning his purpose on himself, were not that the way?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: The most direct path for your safety. For where doth danger sit more furious than in a desperate man?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And being you have declined his means, you have increased his malice.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Besides the general report that steems in every man's breath, and stains you all over with infamy, that time the devourer of all things cannot eat out.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Ay, for that former familiarity, which he had with your lady.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Men speak it as boldly as words of compliment; good morrow, good even, or God save you sir, are not more usual; if the word cuckold had been written upon your forehead in great capital letters, it could not have been dilated with more confidence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He shall not sleep another night, I will have his blood, though it be required at my hands again.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Your lordship may, and without hazarding your own person; he's a gentleman in whose looks I see a resolution to perform it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Let his lordship give me but his honourable word for my life, I'll kill him as he walks.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Or pistol him as he sits at meat.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Or at game.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Or as he is drinking.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Any way.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Wot thou? call what is mine thine own, thy reputation shall not be brought in question for it, much less thy life; it shall be named a deed of valour in thee, not murder: farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: I need no more encouragement, it is a work I will persuade myself that I was born to.

sp.speaker: Laver.
sp.p: And you may persuade yourself to that you shall be saved by it, being that it is for his honourable lordship.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But you must yield me means, how, when and where.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: That shall be burr tasks;
Nay more, we will be agents with thee:
This hour we are to meet him, on the receipt of certain moneys,
Which indeed we purpose honestly to cheat him of,
And that's the many causes I would have him slain,
Who works with safety makes a double gain. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Stay sir, I have taken some pains to overtake you.
— you name is Longaville?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I have the word of many honest men for't, I crave your lordship's pardon, your sudden apprehension on my steps made me to frame an answer unwitting and unworthy your respect.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I know not you; nor am I well pleased to make this time, as the affair now stands, the induction of your acquaintance; you are a fighting fellow?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How my lord?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I think I too much grace you; rather you are a fellow dares not fight, but spit and puff and make a noise whilst your trembling hand draws out your sword, to lay it upon andirons, stools or tables, rather than on a man.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your honour may best speak this; yet — with little safety, if I thought it serious.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Come, you are a merry braggart, and you have given me cause to tell you so: what weakness have you ever seen in me to prompt yourself, that I could need your help, or what other reasons could induce you to it? you never yet had a meal's meat from my table, nor as I remember from my wardrobe any cast suit.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I never durst yet have such a service spirit, to be the minion of a full swollen lord; but always did detest such slavery: a meal's meat, or a cast suit? I would first eat the stones, and from such rags the dunghills does afford pick me a garment.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I have mistook the man, his resolute spirit
Proclaims him generous, he has a noble heart
As free to utter good deeds as to act them;
For had he not been right, and of one piece,
He would have crumpled, curled, and struck himself
Out of the shape of man into a shadow.
But prithee tell me, if no such fawning hope
Did lead thee on to hazard life for my sake;
What was it that incited thee?
Tell me; speak it without the imputation of a sycophant.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your own desert, and with it was joined the unfeigned friendship that I judged you ever held unto my former lord.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: The noble Montague?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, the noble and much injured Montague.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: To such a man as thou art, my heart shall be
A casket: I will lock thee up there,
And esteem thee as a faithful friend,
The richest jewel that a man enjoys;
And being thou didst follow once my friend,
And in thy heart still dost, not with his fortunes casting him off,
Thou shalt go hand in hand with me, and share
As well in my ability as love; 'tis not my end
To gain men for my use, but a true friend. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: There's no such thriving way to live in grace,
As to have no sense of it; his back nor belly
Shall not want warming that can practise me mischief;
I walk now with a full purse, grow high and wanton,
Prune and brisk myself in the bright shine
Of his good lordship's favours; and for what virtue?
For fashioning myself a murderer.
O noble Montague, to whom I owe my heart,
With all my best thoughts, though my tongue have promised
To exceed the malice of thy destiny,
Never in time of all my service knew I
Such a sin tempt thy bounty; those that did feed
Upon thy charge had merit or else need.

div.stage: Enter Laverdine and Lapoope, with disguises.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Duboys, most prosperously met.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: How now? will he come this way.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: This way, immediately; therefore thy assistance, dear duboys.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: What have you cheated him of the money you spoke of?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Fough, as easily as a silly country wench of her maidenhead; we had it in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: 'Tis well captain, let me help you, you must be our leader in this action.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Tut, fear not, I'll warrant you if my sword hold, we'll make no sweating sickness of it.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Why that's well said, but let's retire a little, that we may come on the more bravely; this way, this way.

div.stage: Enter Montague in the hands of three officers, and three creditors.

sp.speaker: 1 cre.
sp.p: Officers look to him, and be sure you take good security before he part from you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why but my friends, you take a strange course with me; the sums I owe you are rather forgetfulness they are so slight, then want of will or honesty to pay you.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.p: Ay sir, it may be so; but we must be paid, and we will be paid before you scape: we have wife and children, and a charge, and you are going down the wind, as a man may say; and therefore it behooves us to look to't in time.

sp.speaker: 2 creditor
sp.p: Your cloak here would satisfy me, mine's not above a three pound matter, besides the arrest.

sp.speaker: 3 creditor
sp.p: Faith and mine is much about that matter too; your girdle and hangers, and your beaver, shall be sufficient bail for't.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.p: If you have ever a plain black suit at home, this silken one, with your silk-stockings, garters, and roses shall pacify me too; for I take no delight, if I have a sufficient pawn, to cast any gentleman in prison; therefore 'tis but an untrussing matter, and you are free, we are no unreasonable creatures you see; for mine own part, I protest I am loath to put you to any trouble for security.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Is there no more of you? he would next demand my skin.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.p: No sir, here's no more of us, nor do any of us demand your skin, we know not what to do with it: but it may be if you owed your glover any money, he knew what use to make of it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ye dregs of baseness, vultures amongst men,
That tire upon the hearts of generous spirits.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.p: You do us wrong sir, we tire no generous spirits, we tire nothing but our hackneys.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But here comes one made of another piece;
A man well meriting that free born name
Of citizen; welcome my deliverer, I am fallen
Into the hands of bloodhounds, that for a sum
Lesser than their honesties, which is nothing,
Would tear me out of my skin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 cre.
sp.p: Why sir, the matter is, that we must have our money, which if we cannot have, we'll satisfy ourselves with his carcase, and be paid that ways: you had as good sir not have been so peremptory. Officer, hold fast.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: The strenuous fist of vengeance now is clutched; therefore fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What may be the debt in gross?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Some forty crowns, nay rather not so much, 'tis quickly cast.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Tis strange to me, that your estate should have so low an ebb, to stick at such sleight sums: why my friends, you are too strict in your accounts, and call too sudden on this gentleman, he has hopes left yet to pay you all.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.p: Hopes? I marry bid him pay his friends with hopes, and pay us with currant coin: I knew a gallant once that fed his creditors still with hopes, and bid 'em they should fear nothing, for he had 'em tied in a string; and trust me so he had indeed, for at last he and all his hopes hopped in a halter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Good sir, with what speed you may free out the company of these slaves, that have nothing but their names to show 'em men.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What would you wish me do sir? I protest I ha' not the present sum (Small as it is) to lay down for you; and for giving my word, my friends no latter than yesternight made me take bread and eat it, that I should not do it for any man breathing ith' world; therefore I pray bold me excused.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You do not speak this seriously?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As ever I said my prayers, I protest to you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What may I think of this?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Troth sir thought is free for any man; we abuse our betters in it, I have done it myself.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Trust me, this speech of yours doth much amaze me, pray leave this language, and out of that same sum you lately did receive of me, lay down as much as may discharge me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You are a merry man sir, and I am glad you take your crosses so temperately; fare you well sir, and yet I have something more to say to ye, a word in your ear I pray; to be plain with you I did lay this plot to arrest you to enjoy this money I have of yours, with the more safety. I am a fool to tell you this now; but in good faith I could not keep it in. And the money would a done me little good else. An honest citizen cannot wholly enjoy his own wife for you, they grow old before they have true use of them, which is a lamentable thing, and truly much hardens the hearts of us citizens against you: I can say no more, but am heartily sorry for your heaviness, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: 1 creditor
sp.l: Officers take hold on him again, for monsieur
Mallicorne will do nothing for him I perceive.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Nay come my masters, leave dancing of the old measures, and let's assault him bravely.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: By no means; for it goes against my stomach to kill a man in an unjust quarrel.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: It must needs be a clog to a man's conscience all his life time.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: It must indeed captain: besides do ye not see he has gotten a guard of friends about him, as if he had some knowledge of our purpose?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Had he a guard of devils as I think them little better, my sword should do the message that it came for.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If you will be so desperate, the blood lie upon your own neck, for we'll not meddle in't.

div.stage: Duboys runs upon Montague, and struggling yields him his sword; the officers draw, Laverdine and La-poope in the scuffling retire, Montague chaseth them off the stage, himself wounded.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I am your friend and servant,
Struggle with me and take my sword;
Noble sir make your way, you have slain an officer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Some one of them has certainly
Requited me; for I do lose much blood.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: Udsprecious, we have lost a brother, pursue the gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Offic.
sp.p: I'll not meddle with him: you see what comes on't; besides I know he will be hanged ere he be taken.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: I tell thee yeoman he must be taken ere he be hanged; he is hurt in the guts, run afore therefore and know how his wife will rate his sausages a pound.

sp.speaker: 3 Offic.
sp.p: Stay brother, I may live, for surely I find I'm but hurt in the leg a dangerous kick on the shinbone.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter madam Lamira, madam le Orleans, Veramour.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You see lady
What harmless sports ous country life affords;
And though you meet not here with city dainties,
Or courtly entertainment, what you have
Is free and hearty.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Madam, I find here
What is a stranger to the court, content,
And receive courtesies done for themselves,
Without an expectation of return,
Which binds me to your service.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O your love;
My homely house built more for use then show
Observes the golden mean equally distant
From glittering pomp, and sordid avarice;
For masks we will observe the works of nature
And in the place of visitation read.
Our physic shall be wholesome walks, our viands,
Nourishing not provoking: for I find
Pleasures are tortures, that leave stings behind.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: You have a great estate.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A competency
Sufficient to maintain me and my rank,
Nor am I, I thank heaven, so courtly bred
As to employ the utmost of my rends
In paying tailors for fantastic robes;
Or rather than be second in the fashion,
Eat out my officers and my revenues
With grating usury; my back shall not
Be the base on which your soothing citizen
Erects his summer-houses; nor on the other side
Will I be so penuriously wise,
As to make money (That's my slave) my idol,
Which yet to wrong, merits as much reproof,
As to abuse our servant.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Yet with your pardon
I think you want the crown of all contentment.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: In what good madam?

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: In a worthy husband.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: — It is strange the galleyslave should praise
His oar, or strokes; or you, that have made shipwreck
Of all delight upon this rock called marriage,
Should sing encomions of't.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Madam, though one fall
From his horse and break his neck, will you
Conclude from that it is unfit to ride?
Or must it follow, because Orleans
My lord's pleased to make his passionate trial
Of my suspected patience, that my brother,
(Were he not so, I might say, worthy Amiens)
Will imitate his ills, that cannot fancy
What's truly noble in him?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I must grant
There's as much worth in him as can be looked for
From a young lord, but not enough to make
Me change my golden liberty and consent
To be a servant to it, as wives are
To the imperious humours of their lords:
Methinks I'm well, I rise and go to bed
When I think fit, eat what my appetite
Desires without control, my servant's study
Is my contentment, and to make me merry
Their farthest aims; my sleeps are inquired after,
My rising up saluted with respect:
Command and liberty now wait upon
My virgin state; what would I more? change all,
And for a husband? no; these freedoms die,
In which they live with my virginity;
'Tis in their choice that's rich to be a wife,
But not being yoked to choose the single life.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How like you the country?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I like the air of it well madam, and the rather because as on Irish timber your spiders will not make his web, so for ought I see yet your cheater, pander, and informer being in their dispositions too foggy for this piercing climate, shun it, and choose rather to walk in mists in the city.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Who did you serve first boy?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: A rich merchant's widow, and was by her preferred to a young court-lady.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.p: And what difference found you in their service?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Very much: for look how much my old city madam gave to her-young visitants, so much my lady received for her hoary court-servants.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: And what made you to leave her?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: My father (Madam) had a desire to have me a tale-man, took me from thence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Well, I perceive you inherit the wag, from your father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Doves beget doves; and eagles, eagles, madam: a citizen here, though left never so rich, seldom at the best proves a gentleman: the son of an advocate, though dubbed like his father, will show a relish of his descent, and the father's thriving practice, as I have heard: she that of a chambermaid is metamorphosed into a madam, will yet remember how oft her daughter by her mother ventured to lie upon the rushes before she could get in that which makes many ladies.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.p: But what think you of your late master?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: O madam —Sigh.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why do you sigh? you are sorry that you left him,
He made a wanton of you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not for that:
Or if he did, for that my youth must love him.
O pardon me, if I say liberty
Is bondage, if compared with his kind service;
And but to have power now to speak his worth
To its desert; I should be well content
To be an old man when his praise were ended:
And yet, if at this instant you were pleased,
I should begin, the livery of age
Would take his lodging upon this head
Ere I should bring it to a period.
In brief he is a man (For God forbid
That I should ever live to say he was
Of such a shape as would make one beloved,
That never had good thought;) and to his body
He hath a mind of such a constant temper
In which virtues throng to have a room:
Yet 'gainst this noble gentleman, this Montague,
For in that name I comprehend all goodness,
Wrong, and the wrested law, false witnesses,
And envy sent from hell, have rose in arms,
And though not pierced, battered his honoured shield.
What shall I say? I hope you will forgive me,
That if you were but pleased to love,
I know no Juno worthy such a Jove.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis well yet that I have the second place
In your affection: from whence?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: From the lord Amiens, madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis welcome, though it bear his usual language:
I thought so much, his love-suit speak his health.
What's he that brought it?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: A gentleman of good rank, it seems.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Receiving entertainment in your house
Sorting with his degree.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: He waits your ladyship's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He shall not wait long:
I'll leave you for a while; nay stay you boy,
Attend the lady. Exeunt Lam. Charl.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Would I might live once
To wait on my poor master.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: That's a good boy:
This thankfulness looks lovely on thy forehead,
And in it, as a book, methinks I read
Instructions for myself, that am his debtor,
And would do much that I might be so happy
To repair that which to our grief is ruined.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It were a work a King might glory in,
If he saw with my eyes: if you please madam,
For sure to me you seem to me unapt to walk,
To sit, although the churlish birds deny
To give us music in this grove, where they
Are prodigal to others: I'll strain my voice
For a sad song, the place is safe and private.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: 'Twas my desire; begin good Viramour.

div.stage: Music a song, at the end of it enter Montague fainting, his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: What's he Viramour?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: A goodly personage.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Am I yet safe? or is my flight a dream?
My wounds and hunger tell me that I wake:
Whither have my fears born me? no matter where,
Who hath no place to go to, cannot err:
What shall I do? cunning calamity
That others gross wits uses to refine,
When I most need it dulls the edge of mine.

sp.speaker: L O●l.
sp.l: Is not this Montagues voice?

sp.speaker: Vir
sp.l: My masters? fie.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What sound was that, pish,
Fear makes the wretch think every leaf oth' jury:
What course to live, beg? better men have done it,
But in another kind: steal? Alexander
Though styled a conqueror, was a proud thief
Though he robbed with an army; fie how idle
These meditations are: though thou art worse
Than sorrows tongue can speak thee, thou art still
Or shouldst be, honest Montague.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: 'Tis too true.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis he: what villains hands did this? o that my flesh
Were balm; in faith sir, I would pluck it off
As readily as this; pray you accept
My will to do you service: I have heard
The mouse once saved the lion in his need,
As the poor scarab spilt the eagle's seed.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: How do you?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: As a forsaken man.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Do not say so, take comfort,
For your misfortunes have been kind in this,
To cast you on a hospitable shore,
Where dwells a lady —

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: She to whom, good master,
You preferred me.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: In whose house, whatsoever
Your dangers are, I'll undertake your safety.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I fear that I am pursued, and doubt that I
In my defence have killed an officer.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Is that all? there's no law under the sun
But will I hope confess, one drop of blood
Shed from this arm is recompense enough
Though you had cut the throats of all the catchpoles
In France, nay in the world.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I would be loath
To be a burden, or feed like a drone
On the industrious labour of a bee,
And baser far I hold it to owe for
The bread I eat, what's not in me to pay;
Then since my full fortunes are declined,
To their low ebb I'll fashion my high mind.
It was no shame to Hecuba to serve
When Troy was fired: if't be in your power
To be a means to make her entertainment,
And far from that I was; but to supply
My want with habit fit for him that serves,
I shall owe much to you.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Leave that care to me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Good sir, leave on my shoulder; help good madam . o that I were a horse for half an hour, that I might carry you home on my back: I hope you will love me still?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou dost deserve it boy, that I should live
To be thus troublesome.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: Good sir, 'tis none.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Trouble most willingly; I would be changed
Like Apuleius, wear his ass's ears,
Provided I might still this burden bear.

sp.speaker: L. Orl.
sp.l: 'Tis a kind boy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I find true proof of it. Exeunt:

div.stage: Enter Amiens and Longeville with a paper.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You'll carry it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: As I live although my packet were like Bellerophon's, what have you seen in me or my behaviour since your favours so plentifully showed upon my wants, that may beget distrust of my performance?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry, if I entertained
But the least scruple of your love, or courage,
I would make of one which my state
Should do me right in this, nor can you blame me
If in a matter of such consequence
I am so importunate.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Good my lord tell me, prevent your further conjurations
To raise my spirit, I know this is a challenge
To be delivered unto Orleans hand,
And that my undertaking ends not there,
But I must be your second, and in that
Not alone search your enemy, measure weapons,
But stand in all your hazards, as our bloods
Ran in the self same veins, in which if I
Better not your opinion, as a limb
That's putrified and useless, cut me off,
And underneath the gallons bury it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: At full you understand me, and in this
Bind me and what's mine to you and yours,
I will not so much wrong you as to add
One syllable more, let it suffice I leave
My honour to your guard: and in that prove
You hold the first place in my heart and love. Exit Ami.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The first place in a lord's affection? very good; and how long doth that last? perhaps the changing of some three shirts in the tennis court; well it were very necessary that an order were taken (If it were possible,) that younger brother, might have more wit, or more money: for now however the fool hath long been put upon him that inherits his revenue hath brought him a sponge, and wiped off the imputation, and for the understanding of the younger, let him get as much rhetoric as he can to grace his language.
They will see he shall have gloss little enough to set out his bark; stand Dubois look about all safe.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Approach not near me but with reverence
Laurel and adorations, I have done more than deserve a 100 thanks.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: With this hand only aided by this brain,
Without an Orpheus' harp redeemed from hell's
Three headed porter, our Eurydice.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Nay prithee speak sense, this is like the stale braggart in a play.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Then in plain prose thus, and with as little action as thou canst desire, the three headed porter, were three unexorable catchpoles out of whose jaws without the help of Orpheus' harp, bait or bribe, for those too strings, makes the music that mollifies those flinty furies, I rescued our Eurydice, I mean my old master Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And is this all, a poor rescue, I thought thou hadst reversed the judgement for his overthrow, in his suit, or wrought upon his adversary Orleans, taken the shape of a ghost, frighted his mind into distraction, and for the appeasing of his conscience forced him to make restitution of Montagues lands, or such like rescued; slight I would have hired Crohi●ture for two cardecues to have done so much with his whip.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: You wood sir, and yet 'tis more than three on their foot-cloths durst do for a sworn brother, in a coach.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Besides what proofs of it, for ought I know this may be a trick, I had rather have him a prisoner, where I might visit him, and do him service, than not at all, or I know not where.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Well sir, the end will show it, what's that a challenge?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, where's Orleans? though we fight in jest he must meet with Amiens in earnest, — fall off, we are discovered; my horse garcon ha'.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Were it not in a house and in his presence,
To whom I owe all duty —

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What would it do? prate as it does? but be as far from striking as he that owes it Orleans.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I think thou art his porter,
Set here to answer creditors, that his lordship
Is not within or takes the diet. I am sent,
And will grow here until I have an answer,
Not to demand a debt of money, but
To call him to a strict account for wrong
Done to the honours of a gentleman,
Which nothing but his heartblood shall wash off.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Shall I hear this?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And more, that if I may not
Have access to him, I will six this here
To his disgrace and thine.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: And thy life with it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Then have the copies of it pasted on posts,
Like pamphlet titles that sue to be sold;
Have his disgrace talk for tobacco shops,
His picture baffled.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: All respect away, were't in a church — draw both

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This is the book I pray with.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Forbear upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What are you roused? I hope your lordship can read (Though he stain not his birth with scholarship) doth it not please you now? if you are a right monsieur, muster up the rest of your attendance, which is a page, a cook, a pander, coachman, and a foot man, in these days a great lords train, pretending I am unworthy to bring you a challenge, in stead of answering it, have me kicked.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: If he does thou deservest it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I dare you all to touch me, I'll not stand still,
What answer you?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: That thou hast done to Amience
The office of a faithful friend which I
Would cherish in thee were he not my foe,
However since on honourable terms
He calls me forth, say I will meet with him,
And by Dubois ere sunset make him know
The time and place, my sword's length, and whatever
Scruple of circumstance he can expect.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This answer comes unlooked for, far you well,
Finding your temper thus, wood I had said less. Exit.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Now comes thy love to the test.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: My lord 'twill hold,
And in all dangers prove itself true gold. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I will acquaint my lady with your coming.
Please you repose yourselves here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: There's a tester, nay now I am a wooer I must be bountiful.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: If you would have two three-pences for it sir, to give some of your kindred as you ride, I'll see if I can get them; we use not (Though servants) to take bribes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Then thou art unfit, to be in office either in court or city.

sp.speaker: La-p.
