sp.p: Indeed corruption is a tree whose branches are of an unmeasurable length they spread everywhere , and the dew that drops from thence have infected some chairs and stools of authority.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Ah captain, lay not all the fault upon officers
you know you can shark though you be out of action, witness Montague.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Hang him, he's safe enough; you had a hand in it to and have gained by him; but I wonder you citizens that keep so many books, and take such strict accounts for every farthing due to you from others, reserve not so much as a memorandum for the courtesies you receive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Would you have a citizen book those? thankfulness is a thing we are not sworn to in our indentures: you may as well urge conscience.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Talk no more of such vanities. Montague is irrecoverably sunk, I would we had twenty more to send after him; the snake that would be a dragon and have wings must eat; and what employs that but this, that in this cannibal age he that would have the suit of wealth must not care — whom he feeds on? and as I have heard no flesh battens better, than that of a professed friend; and he that would mount to honour must not make dainty to use the head of his mother, back of his father, or neck of his brother, for ladders to his preferment; for but observe, and you shall find for the most part cunning villainy sit at a feast as principal guest, and innocent honesty wait as a contemned servant with a trencher.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: The ladies.

div.stage: Enter Mountague bareheaded, Lamira, lady Orleance, Charlo, Veramour, salute.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Do ye smell nothing?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: The carrion of knaves is very strong in my nostrils.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We came to admire, and find fame was a niggard
Which we thought prodigal in our report
Before we saw you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tush sir, this courtship's old.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I'll fight for thee sweet wench,
This is my tongue and woes for me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good man of war,
Hands of; if you take me it must be by siege,
Not by an onset; and for your valour, I
Think that I have deserved few enemies,
And therefore need it not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thou needst nothing sweet lady, but an obsequious husband, and where wilt thou find him, if not in the city: we are true Moscovits to our wives, and are never better pleased, then when they use us as slaves, bridle and saddle us; have me, thou shalt command all my wealth as thine own, thou shalt sit like a Queen in my ware house; and my factors at the return with my ships shall pay thee tribute of all the rarities of the earth; thou shalt wear gold, feed on delicates, the first peascod-strawberries, grapes, cherries shall —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be mine; I apprehend what you would say,
Those dainties which the city pays so dear for,
The country yields for nothing, and as early;
And credit me your far fetched viands please not
My appetite better than those that are near hand.
Then for your promised service and subjection
To all my humours, when I am your wife,
Which as it seems is frequent in the city,
I cannot find what pleasure they receive
In using there fond husbands like their maids;
But of this more hereafter; I accept
Your proffer kindly, and yours; my house stands open
To entertain you; take your pleasure in it,
And ease after your journey.

sp.speaker: La. Orl.
sp.p: Do you note the boldness of the fellows?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Alas madam, a virgin must in this be like a lawyer,
And as he takes all fees, she must hear all suitors; the
One for gain, the other for her mirth; stay with the
Gentlemen, we'll to the orchards. Exeunt Lamira, la. orle. Veram. Charl.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: — what art thou?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: An honest man, though poor;
And look they like to monsters, are they so rare?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Rose from the dead.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do you hear monsieur serviture, didst thou never hear of one Montague a prodigal gull, that lives about Paris?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: One that after the loss of his main estate in a
Law suit, bought an office in the court.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: And should have letters of mart, to have the Spanish treasure as it came from the Indies; were not thou and he twins? put of thy hat, let me see thy forehead.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Though you take privilege to use your tongues,
I pray you hold your fingers,
'Twas your base cozenage made me as I am,
And were you somewhere else I would take off
This proud film from your eyes, that will not tell you,
Know I am Montague.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I will observe this better.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And art thou he? I will do thee grace; give me thy hand; I am glad thou hast taken so good a course; serve God and please thy mistress; if I prove to be thy master as I am very likely, I will do for thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith the fellow's well made for a servingman, and will no doubt carry a chine of beef with good grace.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Prithee be careful of me in my chamber, I will remember thee at my departure.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: All this I can endure under this roof,
And so much owe I her, whose now I am,
That no wrong shall incense me to molest
Her quiet house; while you continue here,
I will not be ashamed to do you service
More than to her, because such is her pleasure.
But you that have broke thrice, and fourteen times
Compounded for two shillings in the pound,
Know I dare kick you in your shop; do ye hear?
If ever I see Paris, though an army
Of musty morions, rusty brown bills and clubs,
Stand for your guard — I have heard of your tricks,
And you that smell of amber at my charge,
And triumph in your cheat; well I may live
To meet thee, be it among a troop of such
That are upon the fair face of the court
Like running ulcers, and before thy whore
Trample upon thee.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: This a language for a livery? take heed, I am a captain.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A coxcomb are you not? that thou and I
To give proof, which of us dares most, were now
In midst of a rough sea, upon a piece
Of a split ship, where only one might ride,Exit Lamira from the arras.
I would — but foolish anger makes me talk
Like a player.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Indeed you act a part
Doth ill become you my servant; is this your duty?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I crave your pardon, and will hereafter be more circumspect.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
O the power of a woman's tongue! it had
done more than we three with our swords durst undertake: put a mad man to silence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why sirrah these are none of your comrades
To drink with in the cellar; one of them
For ought you know may live to be your master.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: There's some comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Here's choice of three, a wealthy merchant.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hem, she's taken, she hath spied my good calf,
And many ladies choose their husbands by that.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A courtier that's in grace, a valiant captain,
And are these mates for you? away be gone.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I humbly pray you will be pleased to pardon,
And to give satisfaction to you madam.
(Although I break my heart) I will confess
That I have wronged them too, and make submission.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: No I'll spare that; go bid the cook haste supper. Exit Mont.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: O brave lady thou art worthy to have servants, to be commandress of a family, that knowest how to use and govern it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You shall have many mistresses that will so mistake as to take their horse keepers, and footmen instead of their husbands, thou art none of those.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But she that can make distinction of men, and knows when she hath gallants, and fellows of rank and quality in her house —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Gallants indeed, if it be the gallants fashion
To triumph in the miseries of a man,
Of which they are the cause: one that transcends
(In spite of all that fortune hath, or can be done)
A million of such things as you, my doors
Stand open to receive all such as wear
The shape of gentlemen, and my gentlier nature
(I might say weaker) weighs not the expense
Of entertainment; think you I'll forget yet
What's due unto myself? do not I know,
That you have dealt with poor Montague, but like
Needy commanders, cheating citizens,
And perjured courtiers? I am much moved, else use not
To say so much, if you will bear yourselves
As fits such you would make me think you are,
You may stay; if not the way lies before you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What think you of this captain?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: That this is a bawdy house, with pinnacles and turrets, in which this disguised Montague goes to rut great is, and that this is a landed panderess, and makes her house a brothel for charity.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Come, that's no miracle; but from whence derive you the supposition?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Observe but the circumstance; you all know that in the height of Montagues prosperity, he did affect and had his love returned by this lady Orleans; since her divorcement, and his decay of estate, it is known, they have met not so much as his boy is wanting; and that this can be any thing else then a mere plot for their night work, is above my imagination to conceive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay it carries probability, let us observe it better, but yet with such caution as our prying be not discovered: here's all things to be had without cost, and therefore good staying here.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Nay that's true, I would we might woe her twenty years like Penelope's suitors; come laverdine.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I follow instantly, yonder he is.
The thought of this boy hath much cold my affection to his lady, and by all conjectures, this is a disguised whore; I will try if I can search this mine. Page —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: And you a brave man: now I am out of your debt.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I am in haste sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: By the faith of a courtier.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Take heed what you say, you have taken a strange oath.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I have not seen a youth that hath pleased me better, I would thou couldst like me, so far as to leave thy lady and wait on me, I would maintain thee in the bravest clothes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Though you took them up on trust, or bought 'em at the brokers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Or any way: then thy employments should be so neat and cleanly, thou shouldst not touch a pair of pantables in a month, and thy lodging —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Should be in a brothel.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No, but in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: That my be the circle of a bawdy house, or worse.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I mean thou shouldst lie with me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Lie with you? I had rather lie with my lady's monkey; 'twas never a good world since our French lords learned of the Neopolitans; to make their pages their bedfellows, doth more hurt to the suburb ladies then twenty dead vacations; 'tis supper time sir. Exit Veram.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I thought so, I know by that 'tis a woman, for because peradventure she hath made trial of the monkey, she prefers him before me, as one unknown; well these are standing creatures, and have strange desires; and men must use strange means to quench strange fires.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Montague, alone, in mean habit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Now Montague, who discerns thy spirit now?
Thy breeding or thy blood? here's a poor cloud
Eclipseth all thy splendour; who can read
In thy pale face, dead eye, or lenten shoot,
The liberty thy ever giving hand
Hath bought for others, manacling itself
In gives of parchment indissoluble?
The greatest hearted man supplied with means,
Nobility of birth and gentlest parts,
I though the right hand of his sovereign,
If virtue quit her seat in his high soul,
Glitters but like a palace set on fire,
Whose glory whilst it shines, but ruins him,
And his bright show each hour to ashes tending
Shall at the last be raked up like a sparkle,
Unless men's lives and fortunes feed the flame.
Not for my own wants though blame I my stars,
But suffering others to cast love on me,
When I can neither take nor thankful be.
My lady's woman, fair and virtuous
Young as the present month, solicits me
For love and marriage now being nothing worth —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O master, I have sought you a long hour,
Good faith, I never joyed out of your sight;
For god's sake sir be merry, or else bear
The buffets of your fortunes with more scorn;
Do but begin to rail, teach me the way,
And I'll sit down and help your anger forth:
I have known you wear a suit full worth a lordship,
Give to a man whose need ne'er frighted you
From calling of him friend, five hundred crowns
Ere sleep had left your senses to consider
Your own important present uses; yet
Since I have seen you with a trencher wait,
Void of all scorn, therefore I'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Would God thou wert less honest.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Would to God you were less worthy: I am even w'ee sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Is not thy master strangely fallen, when thou
Servest for no wages, but for charity?
Thou dost surcharge me with thy plenteous love:
The goodness of thy virtue shown to me,
More opens still my disability
To quit thy pains: credit me loving boy,
A free and honest nature may be oppressed,
Tired with courtesies from a liberal spirit,
When they exceed his means of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But 'tis a due in him that to that end
Extends his love or duty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Little world
Of virtue, why dost love and follow me?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I will follow you through all countries,
I'll run (Fast as I can) by your horse side,
I'll hold your stirrup when you do alight,
And without grudging wait till you return:
I'll quit offered means, and expose myself
To cold and hunger still to be with you;
Fearless I'll travel through a wilderness,
And when you are weary, I will lay me down
That in my bosom you may rest your head,
Where whilst you sleep, I'll watch that no wild beast
Shall hurt or trouble you: and thus we'll breed a story
To make every hearer weep,
When they discourse our fortunes and our loves.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O what a scoff might men of worms make,
If they did know this boy? but my desire
Is that thou wouldst not (As thou usest still
When like a servant I 'mong servants sit)
Wait on my trencher, fill my cups with wine:
Why shouldst thou do this boy? prithee consider,
I am not what I was.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Cursed be the day when I forget that Montague was my lord, or not remember him my master still.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Rather curse me, with whom thy youth hath spent
So many hours, and yet untaught to live
By any worldly quality.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Indeed you never taught me how to handle cards
To cheat and coz in men with oaths and lies;
Those are the worldly qualities to live:
Some of our scarlet gallants teach their boys
These worldly qualities.
Since stumbling fortune then leaves virtue thus
Let me leave fortune, ere be vicious.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O lad, thy love will kill me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: In truth, I think in conscience I shall die for you:
Good master weep not, do you want aught sir?
Will you have any money? here's some silver;
And here's a little gold, 'twill serve to play,
And put more troublesome thoughts out of your mind:
I pray sir take it, I'll get more with singing.
And then I'll bring it you; my lady ga't me,
And — it was not covetousness,
But I forgotten to tell you sooner on't.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Alas boy, thou art not bound to tell it me,
And less to give it, buy thee scarves and garters,
And when I have money, I will give thee a sword:
Nature made thee a beauteous cabinet
To lock up all the goodness of the earth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I have lost my voice with the very sight of this gentlewoman: good sir steal away, you were wont to be a curious avoider of women's company.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy, thou dar'st trust me anywhere , dar'st thou not?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I had rather trust you by a roaring lion, than a ravening woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why truly she devours more man's flesh —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Ay, but she roars not boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No sir, why she is never silent but when her mouth is full.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Monsieur Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My sweet fellow, since you please to call me so.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ah my conscience she would be pleased well enough to call you bedfellow: o master, do not hold her by the hand so: a woman is a limebush, that catcheth all she toucheth.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I do most dangerously suspect this boy to be a wench; art thou not one? come hither, let me feel thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Why dost thou pull off thy glove?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, to feel whether you be a boy, or no.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Fie boy, go too, I'll not look your head, nor comb your locks any more, if you talk thus.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, I'll sing to you no more then.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Fie upon't, how sad you are? A young gentleman that was the very sun of France.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: But I am in the eclipse now.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Suffer himself to be overrun with a lethargy of melancholy and discontent! rouse up thy spirit, man, and shake it off:
sp.l: A noble soul is like a ship at sea,
That sleeps at anchor when the ocean's calm;
But when she rages, and the wind blows high,
He cuts his way with skill and majesty.
sp.p: I would turn a fool, or poet, or any thing, or marry, to make you merry; prithee let's walk: good veramour leave thy master and me, I have earnest business with him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Pray do you leave my master, and me; we were very merry before you came, he does not covet women's company.
sp.l: What have you to do with him? come sir will you go?
And I'll sing to you again:
sp.p: I'faith his mind is stronger than to credit women's vows, and too pure to be capable of their loves.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: The boy is jealous; sweet lad leave us; my lady called for you I swear: that's a good child, there's a piece of gold for thee, go buy a feather.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
There's two pieces for you, do you go and buy one, or what you will, or nothing so you go. Nay then I see you would have me go sir; why, i'faith I will; now I perceive you love her better than you do me; but
God bless you whatever you do, or intend; I know you are a very honest man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Still shall I woe thee, whilst thy ears reply
I cannot, or I will not marry thee?
Why hast thou drawn the blood out of my cheeks,
And given a quicker motion to my heart?
O thou hast bred a fever in my veins
Called love, which no physician can cure;
Have mercy on a maid whose simple youth —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How your example fairest teacheth me
A ceremonious idolatry!Kneels.
By all the joy of love I love thee better
Than I or any man can tell another;
And will express the mercy which thou cravest,
I will forbear to marry thee: consider
Thou art nature's heir in feature, and thy parents
In fair inheritances; rise with these thoughts,
And look on me; but with a woman's eye,
A decayed fellow, void of means and spirit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Of spirit?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes, could I tamely live,
Forget my father's blood, wait and make legs,
Stain my best breeches, with the servile drops
That fall from others draughts:

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: This vizard wherewith thou wouldst hide thy spirit
Is perspective, to show it plainlier.
This undervalue of thy life is but
Because I should not buy thee; what more speaks
Greatness of man, then valiant patience,
That shrinks not under his fate's strongest strokes?
These Roman deaths, as falling on a sword,
Opening of veins, with poison quenching thirst,
(Which we erroneously do style the deeds
Of the heroic and magnanimous man)
Was dead-eyed cowardice, and white cheek fear,
Who doubting tyranny, and fainting under
Fortune's false lottery, desperately run
To death for dread of death; that souls most stout,
That bearing all mischance, dares last it out;
Will you perform your word, and marry me,
When I shall call you to't?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Who's this alights here?

sp.speaker: Long,
sp.p: With leave fair creature, are you the lady mistress of the house?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Her servant sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I pray then favour me, to inform your lady, and
Duke Orleans wife,
A business of import awaits 'em here,
And craves for speedy answer.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Are you in post sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, I am in satin lady; I would you would be in post.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I will return. Sweet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Honest friend, do you belong to the house?
I pray be covered.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Ha, dreamest thou Longaville? sure 'tis not he: sir
I should know you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So should I you, but that I am ashamed.
But though thou knowest me, prithee Longaville,
Mock not my poverty, pray remember yourself;
Shows it not strangely for thy clothes to stand
Without a hat to mine? mock me no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: She — embroider me all over sir,
If ever I began to mock you yet.
The — on me, why should I wear velvet
And silver lace, — I will tear it off.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why madman?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Put on my hat? yes, when I am hanged I will:
— I could break my head
For holding eyes that knew not you at first:
But time and fortune run your courses with him,
He'll laugh and storm you, when you show most hate.

div.stage: Enter Lamira, Orleans lady, Laverdine, la Poope, Malycorne, Veramour, Charlot:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You're a fair monsieur.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Do you mock me lady?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Your business sir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Regard yourself good monsieur Longueville.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are too negligent of yourself and place,
Cover your head sweet monsieur.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Mistake me not fair ladies,
'Tis not to you, nor you, that I stand bare.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nay sweet dear monsieur, let it not be to us then.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: — a compliment.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And — of manners.
Pray hide your head, your gallants use to do't.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And you your foreheads, why you needful accessary rascals,
That cannot live without your mutual knaveries,
More than a bawd, a pander, or a whore
From one another; how dare you suspect
That I stand bare to you? what make you here?
Shift your house lady of 'em, for I know 'em,
They come to steal napkins, and your spoons;
Look to your silver-bodkin, (Gentlewoman)
'Tis a dead utensil, and page 'Ware your pockets;
My reverence is unto this man, my master,
Whom you with protestations, and oaths
As high as heaven, as deep as hell, which would
Deceive the wisest man of honest nature,
Have cozened and abused; but I may meet you,
And beat you one with tother.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Peace, no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I am something thick of hearing; what said he?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I hear him, but regard him not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor I, I am never angry fasting.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My love keeps back my duty, noblest lady;
If husband or brother merit love from you,
Prevent their dangers, this hour brings to trial
Their hereto sleeping hates; by this time each
Within a yard is of the others heart,
And met to prove their causes and their spirits
With their impartial swords points; haste and save,
Or never meet them more but at the grave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O my distracted heart, that my wrackt honour should for a brother's, or a husband's life, through thy undoing die.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Amiens engaged; if he miscarry all my hopes and joys,
I now confess it loudly, are undone:
Caroche, and haste, one minute may betray
A life more worth than all time can repay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Hump: monsieur Laverdine pursues this boy extremely. Captain what will you do?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Any thing but follow to this sea-service; I am a sea-captain you know, and to offer to part 'em, without we could do't like watermen with long staves, a quarter of a mile off, might be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then let's retire and pray for 'em, I am resolved to stop your intent; abused more than we have been we cannot be, without they fall to flat beating o'us.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And that were unkindly done i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: — but you are the troublesomest ass that ere I met with; retire, you smell like a woman's chamber, that's newly up, before she have pinched her vapours in with her clothes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I will haunt thee like thy grandames ghost, thou shalt never rest for me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Well, I perceive 'tis vain to conceal a secret from you: believe it sir, indeed I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why la; I knew't, this prophetical tongue of mine never failed me; my mother was half a witch, never any thing that she forespoke, but came to pass: a woman? how happy am I? now we may lawfully come together without fear of hanging; sweet wench, be gracious, in honourable sort I woe, no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Faith the truth is I have loved you long.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: See, see.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But durst not open it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: — I think so.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But briefly, when you bring it to the test, if there be not one gentleman in this house, will challenge more interest in me, than you can, I am at your disposure.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O Fortunatus, I envy thee not
For cap, or pouch, this day I'll prove my fortune,
In which your lady doth elect her husband,
Who will be Amiens, 'twill save my wedding dinner,
Povera, la-poop and Malicorne: if all fail,
I will turn citizen, a beauteous wife
Is the hornbook to the richest tradesman's life.

div.stage: Enter duboys, Orleans, Longueville, Amiens, two Lacques, a page wish two pistols.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: Here's a good even piece of ground my lords:
Will you fix here?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes anywhere ; lackey, take off my spurs;
Upon a bridge, a rail but my sword's breadth, upon a battlement,
I'll fight this quarrel.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: On the ropes, my lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Upon a line.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: So all our country duels are carried, like a firework on a thread.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Go now stay with the horses, and do you hear
Upon your lives, till some of us come to you,
Dare not to look this way.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Except you see strangers or others that by chance or purpose are like to interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then give warning.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Who takes a sword? the advantage is so small,
As he that doubts hath the free leave to choose.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Come give me any, and search me; 'tis not
The ground, weapon, or seconds that can make
Odds in those fatal trials: but the cause.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Most true, and but it is no time to wish
When men are come to do, I would desire
The cause 'twixt us were other than it is;
But where the right is, there prevail our swords.
And if my sister have outlived her honour,
I do not pray I may outlive her shame.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Your sister Amiens, is a whore, at once.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You oft have spoke that sense to me before,
But never in this language Orleans;
And when you spoke it fair, and first, I told you
That it was possible you might be abused:
But now, since you forget your manners, you shall find,
If I transgress my custom, you do lie,
And are a villain, which I had rather yet
My sword had proved, than I been forced to speak:
Nay give us leave, and since you stand so haughtily
And highly on your cause, let you and I,
Without engaging these two gentlemen, singly determine it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My lord, you'll pardon us.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: I trust your lordships may not do us that affront.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: We kiss your lordship's hand, and come to serve you here with swords.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My lord, we understand ourselves.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: We have had the honour to be called unto the business, and we must not now quit it on terms.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Not terms of reason?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, no reason for the quitting of our calling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: True if I be called to't I must ask no reason.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Nor hear none neither, which is less:
It is a favour if my throat be cut,
Your lordship does me; which I never can,
sp.stage: A noise within, crying down with their swords.
sp.l: Nor must have hope how to requite: what noise,
What cry is that my lord upon your guard?
Some treachery is a foot.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O here they are:
My lord (Dear lady help me) help me all;
I have so woeful interest in both,
I know not which to fear for most: and yet
I must prefer my lord. Dear brother,
You are too understanding, and too noble
To be offended, when I know my duty,
Though scarce my tears will let me so to do it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Out loathed strumpet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my dearest lord,
If words could on me cast the name of whore,
I then were worthy to be loathed; but know,
Your unkindness cannot make me wicked;
And therefore should less use that power upon me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Was this your art to have these actors come,
To make this interlude? withdraw, cold man,
And if thy spirit be not frozen up,
Give me one stroke yet at thee for my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Thou shalt have strokes, and strokes, thou glorious man,
Till thou breathest thinner air than that thou talkest.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My lord count Amiens.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Princely husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Whore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You wrong her impudent lord; oh that I had the bulk
Of those dull men; look how they stand, and no man
Will revenge an innocent lady.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: You hinder it madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I would hinder you; is there none else to kill him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Kill him madam? have you learned that bad language? O repent,
And be the motive, rather both kill me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then die my infamy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Hold bloody man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Art thou their basilisk?

sp.speaker: Mont:
sp.p: To strike thee dead, but that thy fate deserves some weightier hand.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: O here's a plot; you bring your champions with you; the adultress with the adulterer: out howling —

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Good my lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Are you her grace's countenance lady, the
receiver to the poor vicious couple.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Sweet rascal, didst not thou tell me, false fellow,
This Montague, here was murdered?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: I did so; but he was falser, and a worthless lord,
Like thy foul self, that would have had it so.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Orleans 'tis true, and shall be proved upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Thy malice Duke, and this thy wicked nature, are all as visible as thou; but I born to contemn thy injuries, do know, that though thy greatness may corrupt a jury, and make a judge afraid, and carry out a world of devils with thy title: yet thou art not quiet at home, thou bearest about thee that, that doth charge thee, and condemn thee too. The thing that grieves me more, and doth indeed displease me, is, to think that so much baseness stands here to have encountered so much honour: pardon me my lord what late my passion spoke, when you provoked my innocence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yes do, oh flattery becomes him better than the suit he wears; give him a new one Amiens.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Orleans, 'tis here no time nor place, to jest or rail
Poorly with you, but I will find a time to
Whisper you forth to this or some fit place,
As shall not hold a second interruption.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I hope your lordship's honour, and your life
Are destined unto higher hazards; this is of
A meaner arm.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Yes faith, or none.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He is not fit to fall by an honest sword,
A prince and lie!

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.l: And slander, and hire men
To publish the false rumours he hath made.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And stick 'em on his friends, and innocents.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: And practice against their lives after their fames.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In men that are the matter of all lewdness,
Bands, thieves, and cheaters, it were monstrous.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But in a man of blood, how more conspicuous?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: They do slander him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Hang them, a pair of railing hangbies.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: How? stand Orleans; stay, give me my pistols boy,
Hinder me not, by —
I will kill him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O stay his fury,

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longueville, my friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Not for myself, my lord, but for mankind,
And all that have an interest to virtue,
Or title unto innocence.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Why hear me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: For justice' sake.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That cannot be.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: To punish his wives, your honour, and my lords wrongs here, whom I must ever call so; for your loves I'll swear, I'll sacrifice —

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longaville, I did not think you a murderer before.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I care not what you thought me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By — if thou attempt
His life, thy own is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Foolish frantic man, the murder will be of us, not him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: We could have killed him, but we would not take
The justice out of fates. —
Sing but a hair of him, thou diest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No matter, shoot.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Villain.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: My lord, your sister is slain.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Biancha?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O hapless and most wretched chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Standst thou looking upon the mischief thou hast made
Thou godless man, feeding thy bloodshot eyes
With the red spectacle, and art not turned to stone
With horror? hence and take the wings of thy black
Infamy, to carry thee beyond the shoot of looks,
Or sound of curses, which will pursue thee still:
Thou hast out-fled all but thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O wish it off again, for I am cracked
Under the burden, and my heart will break.
How heavy guilt is, when men come to feel
If you could know the mountain I sustain
With horror, you would each take off your part,
And more, to ease me: I cannot stand,
Forgive where I have wronged I pray.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Look to him Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My lords and gentlemen, the lady is well, but for fear,
Unless that have shot her;
I have the worst on't, that needs would venture
Upon a trick had like to ha' cost my guts:
Look to her, she'll be well, it was but powder
I charged with, thinking that a guilty man
Would have been frighted sooner; but I am glad
He's come at last.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How is Byancha? well?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Lives she? see sister, doth she breathe?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O gentlemen, think you I can breathe,
That am restored to the hateful sense
Of feeling in me my dear husband's death?
O no, I live not; life was that I left;
And what you have called me to, is death indeed;
I cannot weep so fast as he doth bleed.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Pardon me madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha my husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I cannot speak whether my joy or shame
Be greater, but I thank the heavens for both.
O look not black upon me, all my friends,
To whom I will be reconciled, or grow unto
This earth, till I have wept a trench
That shall be great enough to be my grave,
And I will think them too most manly tears,
If they do move your pities: it is true,
Man should do nothing that he should repent;
But if he have, and say that he is sorry,
It is a worse fault if he be not truly.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My lord, such sorrow cannot be suspected:
Here take your honoured wife, and join your hands.
— she hath married you again:
And gentlemen, I do invite you all,
This night to take my house, where on the morrow,
To heighten more the reconciling feast,
I'll make myself a husband and a guest. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well now I am sure you are mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I am sure I am glad
I have one to own then; you'll find me honest
As these days go, enough; poor without question,
Which beggars hold a virtue; give me meat, and I
Shall do my work, else knock my shoes off,
And turn me out again.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You are a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I have no great cause.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yes thy love to me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That's as we make our game.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why you repent then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Faith no worse than I am I cannot be;
Much better I expect not: I shall love you,
And when you bid me go to bed, obey,
Lie still or move, as you shall minister,
Keep a four-nobles nag, and a black
Merling, learn to love ale, and play at two-hand Irish,
And there's then all I aim at.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Nay sweet fellow, I'll make it something better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If you do, you'll make me worse:
Now I am poor, and willing to do well,
Hold me in that course, of all the Kings creatures,
I hate his coin, keep me from that, and save me;
For if you chance out of your housewifery
To leave a hundred pound or two, bestow it
In plumbroth ere I know it, else I take it;
Seek out a hundred men that want this money,
Share it among 'em, they'll cry noble Montague,
And so I stand again at livery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You have pretty fancies sir, but married once,
This charity will fall home to yourself.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I would it would, I am afraid my looseness
Is yet scarce stopped, though it have naught to work on
But the mere air of what I have had.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Pretty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I wonder sweet heart why you'll marry me,
I can see nothing in myself deserves it,
Unless the handsome wearing of a band,
For that's my stock now, or a pair of garters,
Necessity will not let me lose.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I see sir a great deal more, a handsome man, a husband
To make a right good woman truly happy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lord, where are my eyes? either you are foolish
As wenches once a year are, or far worse,
Extremely virtuous, can you love a poor man
That relies on cold meat and cast stockings,
One only suit to his back, which now is mewing?
But what will be the next coat will pose Tristram.
If I should levy from my friends a fortune:
I could not raise ten groats to pay the priest now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I'll do that duty; 'tis not means nor money
Makes me pursue your love; were your mind bankrupt,
I would never love you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Peace wench, here's my lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Nay never shrink i'th wetting, for my presence;
D'ye find her willing Montague?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Willing madam?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How dainty you make of it, do not I know
You two love one another?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Certain madam, I think you've revelations of these matters:
Your ladyship cannot tell me when I kissed her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But she can, sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But she will not madam;
For when they talk once, 'tis like fairy-money,
They get no more close kisses.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou art wanton.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: God knows I need not, yet I would be lusty:
But — my provender scarce pricks me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: It shall be mended Montague, I am glad you are grown so merry.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So am I too madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You two will make a pretty handsome consort.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes madam, if my fiddle fail me not.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Your fiddle? why your fiddle? I warrant thou meanest madly:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Can you blame me? alas I am in love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis very well sir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How long have you been thus?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How thus in love?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are very quick sir: no, I mean thus pleasant.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: — Ever since I was poor.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A little wealth would change you then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes lady into another suit, but never more
Into another man: I'll bar that mainly,
The wealth I get henceforward shall be charmed
For ever hurting me, I'll spend it fasting:
As I live noble lady there is nothing
I have found directly cures the melancholy,
But want and wedlock; when I had store of money
I simpered sometime, and spoke wondrous wise,
But never laughed outright; now I am empty
My heart sounds like a bell, and strikes at both sides.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are finely tempered Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Pardon lady, if any way my free mirth have offended,
'Twas meant to please you: if it prove too saucy,
Give it a frown, and I am ever silenced.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I like it passing well; pray follow it:
This is my day of choice, and shall be yours too,
'Twere pity to delay ye: call to the steward,
And tell him 'tis my pleasure he should give you
500 crowns: make yourself handsome Montague,
Let none wear better clothes, 'tis for my credit;
But pray be merry still.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If I be not, and make a fool of twice as many hundreds,
Clap me in canvas lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I am strangely glad, I have found the mystery
Of this disguised boy out: I ever trusted
It was a woman, and how happily
I have found it so; and for myself, I am sure
One that would offer me a thousand pound now
(And that's a pretty sum to make one stagger)
In ready Gold for this concealment, could not
Buy my hope of her, she's a dainty wench,
And such a one I find ▪ I want extremely
To bring me into credit: beauty does it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Say we should all meach here, and stay the feast, now what can the worst be? we have played the knaves, that's without question.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: True, and as I take it this is the first truth
We told these ten years, and for any thing
I know may be the last: but grant we are knaves,
Both base and beastly knaves —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Say so then.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: And likewise let it be considered, we have wronged
And most maliciously, this gentlewoman,
We cast to stay with, what must we expect now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I there's the point, we would expect good eating.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I know we would, but we may find good beating.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You say true gentlemen, and by —
Though I love meat as well as any man,
I care not what he be, if 'a eat a god's name;
Such crab-sauce to my meat will turn my palate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: There's all the hazard, for the frozen Montague
Has now got spring again, and warmth in him,
And without doubt dares beat us terribly.
For not to mint the matter, we are cowards,
And have and shall be beaten when men please
To call us into cudgelling.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I feel we are very prone that way.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The sons of Adam.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Now here then rests the state o'th question?
Whether we yield our bodies for a dinner
To a sound dog-whip, for I promise ye
If men be given to correction,
We can expect no less, or quietly
Take a hard egg or two, and ten mile hence
Bait in a ditch, this we may do securely;
For to stay here about will be all one,
If once our moral mischiefs come in memory.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But pray ye hear me, is not this the day
The virgin lady doth elect her husband?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The dinner is to that end.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Very well then, say we all stay, and say we all scape this whipping, and be well entertained, and one of us carry the lady.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: 'Tis a seemly saying, I must confess, but if we stay, how fitly
We may apply it to ourselves (I'th end)
Will ask a Christian fear; I cannot see
If I say true, what special ornaments
Of art or nature, lay aside our lying
Whoring and drinking, which are no great virtues,
We are endued withal to win this lady.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yet women go not by the best parts ever; that I have found directly.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why should we fear then? they choose men
As they feed; some times they settle
Upon a white brothed face, a sweet smooth gallant,
And him they make an end of in a night;
Sometimes a goose, sometimes, a grosser meat,
A rump of beef will serve 'em at some season,
And fill their bellies too: though without doubt
They are great devourers: stock fish is a dish,
If it be well dressed, for the tufnesse sake
Will make the proudest of 'em long and leap for't.
They'll run mad for a pudding ere they'll starve,

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: For my own part I care not, come what can come,
If I be whipped, why so be it; if cudgeled,
I hope I shall out live it, I am sure
'Tis not the hundreth time I have been served so,
And yet I thank God I am here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here's resolution.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: A little patience, and a rotten apple
Cures twenty worse diseases; what say you sir?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Marry I say sir, if I had been acquainted
With lamming in my youth, as you have been
With whipping, and such benefits of nature,
I should do better: as I am, I'll venture,
And if it be my luck to have the lady,
I'll use my fortune modestly; if beaten
You shall not hear a word, one I am sure of,
And if the worst fall she shall be my physic.
Let's go then, and a merry wind be with us.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Captain your shoes are old, pray put 'em off,
And let one fling 'em after us; be bold sirs,
And howosever our fortune falls, let's bear
An equal burden; if there be an odd lash,
We'll part it afterwards.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: I am armed at all points.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter four serving in a banquet.

sp.p: Then my lady will have a bedfellow tonight .
So she says, heaven what a dainty armful shall he enjoy that has the launching of her, what a fight she'll make.
I marry boys, there will be sport indeed, there will be grappling, she has a murderer lies in her prow, I am afraid will fright his main mast Robin.
Who dost thou think shall have her of thy conscience, thou art a wise man.
If she go the old way, the way of lot, the longest cut sweeps all without question?
She has lost a friend of me else; what think ye of the courtier.
Hang him hedgehog, has nothing in him but a piece of Euphues, and twenty dozen of twelve penny ribbon all about him, he is but one pedlar's shop of gloves and garters, pickteeth and pomander.
The courtier! marry God bless her Steven, she is not mad yet, she knows that trindle tail too well, he's crest fallen, and pinbuttocked with leaping laundresses.
The merchant sure she will not be so base to have him.
I hope so Rohin, he'll sell us all to the Moors to make mummy; nor the captain.
Who potgun, that's a sweet youth indeed, will he stay think ye?

Yes, without question, and have half dined too ere the grace be done; he's good for nothing in the world but eating, lying and sleeping; what other men devour in drink, he takes in pottage, they say has been at sea, a herring fishing, for without doubt he dares not hail an eel-boat, ith' way of war.
I think so, they would beat him off with butter.

When he brings in a prize, unless it be cockles, or Callis sand to scour with, I'll renounce my five mark a year, and all the hidden art I have in carving, to teach young birds to whistle Walsingham; leave him to the lime boats; now, what think you of the brave Amiens?
That's a thought indeed.
I marry there's a person fit to feed upon a dish so dainty, and he'll do't I warrant him ith' nick boys, has a body world without end.
And such a one my lady will make no little off; but is not Montague married today?
Yes faith, honest Montague must have his bout too.
He's as good a lad as ever turned a trencher; must we leave him?
He's too good for us Steven, I'll give him health to his good luck tonight ith' old beaker, and it shall be sack too.
I must have a garter; and boys I have bespoke, a a posset, somebody shall give me thanks for't, 'thas a few toys in't will raze commotions in a bed lad.
Away; my lady.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Orleance, and his lady arm in arm, Amiens, Lamira, Charlote, like a bride, Montague brave, Laverdine, Longavile Dubois, Mallycorn, La-poope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Stur yourselves noble lords and gentlemen,
You know your places; many royal welcomes
I give your grace; how lovely shows this change?
My house is honoured in this reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thus madam must you do, my lady now shall see
You made a woman;
And give you some short lessons for your voyage.
Take her instructions lady, she knows much.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: This becomes you sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My lord must have his will.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: 'Tis all I can do now sweet heart, fair lady;
This to your happy choice brother Amiens,
You are the man I mean it to.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I'll pledge you.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And with my heart.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: With all my love I take it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Noble lords I am proud ye have done this day,
So much content, and me such estimation that this hour
(In this poor house) shall be a league for ever,
For so I know ye mean it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I do lady.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And I my lord.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: You've done a work of honour.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Give me the cup, where this health stops, let
That man be either very sick, or very simple;
Or I am very angry; sir, to you;
Madam methinks this gentleman might sit to;
He would become the best on's.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pray sit down sir, I know the lady of the feast expects not this day so much old custom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down Montague; nay never blush for the matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Noble madam, I have too reasons against it, and I dare not; duty to you first, as you are my lady, and I your poorest servant; next the custom of this day's ceremony.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: As you are my servant, I may command you then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: To my life lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down, and here, I'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Sit down man, never refuse so fair a lady's offer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It is your pleasure madam, not my pride,
And I obey; I'll pledge ye now my lord, monsieur Longavile.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: This to my lady, and her fair choice today, and happiness.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis a fair health, I'll pledge you though I sink for't.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Montague you are too modest; come I'll add a little more wine t'ee, 'twill make you merry, this to the good I wish. —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Honoured lady, I shall forget myself with this great bounty.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: You shall not sir; give him some vine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By heaven you are a worthy woman, and that ▪
Man is blessed can come near such a lady.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Such a blessing wet weather washes.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: At all, I will not go a lip less my lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: 'Tis well cast sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If Montague get more wine, we are like to hear on't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I do not like that sitting there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, methinks he looks like a judge.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now have I a kind a grudging of a beating on me, I fear my hot fit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Drink apace, there's nothing allays a cudgel like it.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, now I'll put my choice to you; who do you hold in all this honoured company a husband fit to enjoy thy lady? speak directly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Shall I speak madam?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, you shall.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Then as I have a soul I'll speak my conscience,
Give me more wine, in vino veritas,
Here's to myself, and Montague have a care.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Speak to th'cause.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, madam; first I'll begin to thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Have at us.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now for a psalm of mercy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You good monsieur, you that bely the noble name of courtier, and think your claim good here, hold up your hand; your worship is indicted here, for a vain glorious fool.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Good, o sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: For one whose wit
Lies in a ten pound waistcoat, yet not warm;
Ye have travelled like a fiddler to make faces,
And brought home nothing but a case of toothpicks.
You would be married, and no less than ladies,
And of the best sort can serve you; thou silk worm
What hast thou in thee to deserve this woman?
Name but the poorest piece of man, good manners,
There's nothing sound about thee, faith thou'st none,
It lies pawned at thy silk man's, for so much lace;
Thy credit which is worse cannot redeem it,
Thy clothes are all the soul thou hast, for so
Thou sav'st them handsome for the next great tilting
Let who will take the tother, thou wert never christened
Upon my conscience (But in barber's water)
Thou art never out o'th basin, thou art rotten,
And if thou dar'st tell truth, thou wilt confess it;
— thy skin
Looks of a chestnut colour, greased with amber
All women that on earth do dwell thou lovest,
Yet none that understand love thee again,
But those that love the spittle, get thee home
Poor painted butter fly, thy summers passed;
Go sweat and eat dry mutton, thou mayst live
To do so well yet; a bruised chamber maid
May fall upon thee, and advance thy follies.
You have your sentence; now it follows captain,
I treat of you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: Pray God I may deserve it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart he speaks, plain.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: That's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You are a rascal captain.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: A fine calling.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A water coward.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: He would make a pretty stuff.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nay I speak freely madam.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Here's none ties you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why shouldst thou dare come hither with a thought
To find a wife here fit for thee? are all
Thy single money whores that fed on carrots,
And filled the high grass with familiars
Fallen of to footmen? prithee tell me truly,
For now I know thou dar'st not lie, couldst thou not
Wish thyself beaten well with all thy heart now,
And out of pain? say that I broke a rib,
Or cut thy nose off, wert not merciful for this ambition?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Do your pleasure sir, beggars must not be choosers.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He longs for beating.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But that I have nobler thoughts possess my soul,
Than such brown biscuit, such a piece of dogfish,
Such a most mangy mackerel eater as thou art
That dares do nothing that belongs toth' sea,
But spue, and catch rats, and fear men of war,
Though thou hast nothing in the world to lose
Aboard thee, but one piece of beef, one musket
Without a cock for peace' sake, and a pitch barrel,
I'll tell thee if my time were not more precious
Than thus to lose it, I would rattle thee,
It may be beat thee, and thy pure fellow,
The merchant there of catskins, till my words,
Or blows, or both, made ye two branded wretches
To all the world hereafter; you would feign to
Venture your bills of lading for this lady;
What would you give now for her? some five frail
Of rotten figs good, godson, would you not sir?
Or a parrot that speaks high Dutch? can all thou ever sawest
Of thine own fraughts from sea, or cozenage
(At which thou art as expert as the devil)
Nay sell thy soul for wealth to, as thou wilt do,
Forfeit thy friends, and raise a mint of money,
Make thee dream all these double could procure
A kiss from this good lady? canst thou hope
She would lie with such a nook of hell as thou art,
And hatch young merchant-furies? o ye dogbolts
That fear no god but dunkirks, I shall see you
Serve in a lousy lime boat, ere I die,
For mouldy cheese and butter Billingsgate
Would not endure, or bring in rotten pippins
To cure blue eyes, and swear they came from China.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Vex 'em no more, alas they shake:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Down quickly on your marrow bones ▪ and thank this lady.
I would not leave you thus else, there are blankets,
And such delights for such knaves ; but fear still;
'Twill be revenge enough, to keep you waking.
Ye have no mind of marriage, ha' ye?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Surely no great mind now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Nor you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, I take it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Two eager suitors.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Troth 'tis wondrous hot, God bless us from him

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: You have told me Montague
Who are not fit to have me, let me know
The man you would point out for me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: There he sits; my lord of Amiens, madam, is my choice, he's noble every way, and worthy a wife with all the dowries of —

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you speak sir out of your friendship to me?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, and out of truth, for I could never flatter.

sp.speaker: Ami
sp.l: I would not say how much I owe you for it,
For that were but a promise, but I'll thank ye,
As now I find you, in despite of fortune,
A fair and noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: My lords I must confess the choice this man hath made
Is every way a great one, if not too great,
And no way to be slighted: yet because
We love to have our own eyes, sometimes now
Give me a little liberty to see,
How I could fit myself, if I were put to't.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Madam we must.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Are ye all agreed?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We be?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Then as I am a maid, I shall choose here.
Montague, I must have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why madam I have learned to suffer more than you can (Out of pity) mock me with this way especially.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Thou think'st I jest now;
But by the love I bear thee, I will have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If you could be so weak, to love a fall'n man,
He must deserve more than I ever can,
Or ever shall (Dear lady;) look but this way
Upon that lord and you will tell me then
Your eyes are no true choosers of good men.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you love him truly?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Yes my lord, I will obey him truly, for I'll marry him, and justly think he that has so well served me with his obedience being born to greatness, must use me nobly of necessity when I shall serve him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: 'Twere a deep sin to cross ye, noble Montague,
I wish ye all content, and am as happy
In my friends good as it were merely mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your lordship does ill to give up your right;
I am not capable of this great goodness,
There sits my wife that holds my troth.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I'll end all, I wooed you for my lady, and now give up my title, alas poor wench, my aims are lower far.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How's this sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: Sweet heart 'tis so, the drift was mine to hide
My purpose till it struck home.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Prithee leave wondering, by this kiss I'll have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Then by this kiss, and this I'll ever serve ye.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This gentleman and I sir must needs hop once more to follow ye.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: As friends and fellows, never as servants more.

sp.speaker: Long. Dub.
sp.p: You make us happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Friend Montague, ye have taught me so much honour, I have found a fault in myself, but thus I'll purge my conscience of it, the late land I took by false play, from you with as much contrition, and entireness of affection to this most happy day again, I render; be master of your own, forget my malice, and make me worthy of your love, l. Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You have won me and honour to your name.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Since your lordship has begun good deeds, we'll follow; good sir forgive us, we are now those men fear you for goodness' sake; those sums of money unjustly we detain from you, on your pardon shall be restored again, and we your servants.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: You are very forward sir, it seems you have money, I pray you lay out, I'll pay you or pray for you, as the sea works.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Their penance sir I'll undertake, so please ye
To grant me on concealment.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Right courtier, still a-begging .

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What is it sir?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: A gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: In my gift?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Yes sir, in yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why bring her forth and take her.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.l: What wench would he have?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Any wench I think.

div.stage: Enter Laverdine and Veramour, like a woman.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: This is the gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Tis my page sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No sir, I am a poor disguised lady?
That like a page have followed you full long for love god-wot.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A lady — laverdine — yes, yes, 'tis a lady.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It may be so, and yet we have lain together,
But by my troth I never found her, lady.

sp.speaker: L Orl.
sp.l: Why wore you boys clothes?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I'll tell you madam,
I took example by 2 or 3. plays, that methought
Concerned me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why made you not me acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Indeed sir I knew it not myself,
Until this gentleman opened my dull eyes,
And by persuasion made me see it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Could his power in words make such a change?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes, as truly woman as yourself my lord.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why but hark you, are not you a woman?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: If hands and face make it not evident, you shall see more.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Breeches, breeches, laverdine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: 'Tis not enough, women may wear those cases.
Search further courtier.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.l: O thou freshwater gudgeon, wouldst thou come
To point of marriage with an Ignoramus?
Thou shouldst have had her urine to the doctors,
The foolishest physician could have made plain
The liquid epicoene; a blind man by the hand
Could have discovered the ring from the stone.
Boy, come, to sea with me, I'll teach thee to climb,
And come down by the rope, nay to eat rats.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I shall devour my master before the prison then,
Sir, I have begun my trade.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Trade? to the city, child, a flatcap will become thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Gentlemen I beseech you molest yourselves no further,
For his preferment it is determined.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I am much ashamed, and if my cheek
Gives not satisfaction, break my head.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your shame's enough sir.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Montague, much joy attend thy marriage bed;
By thy example of true goodness, envy is exiled,
And to all honest men that truth intend,
I wish good luck, fair fate be still thy friend.

div.head: Upon an honest man's fortune.
div.l: You that can look through heaven, and tell the stars,
Observe their kind conjunctions, and their wars;
Find out new lights, and give them where you please,
To those men honours, pleasures, to those ease;
You that are gods surveyors, and can show
How far, and when, and why the wind doth blow;
Know all the charges of the dreadful thunder,
And when it will shoot over, or fall under:
Tell me, by all your art I conjure ye,
Yes, and by truth, what shall become of me?
Find out my star, if each one, as you say,
Have his peculiar angel, and his way;
Observe my fate, next fall into your dreams,
Sweep clean your houses, and new line your sceames,
Then say your worst: or have I none at all?
Or is it burned out lately? or did fall?
Or am I poor, not able, no full flame?
My star, like me, unworthy of a name?
Is it, your art can only work on those
That deal with dangers, dignities, and clothes?
With love, or new opinions? you all lie,
A fishwife hath a fate, and so have I,
But far above your finding; he that gives,
Out of his providence, to all that lives,
And no man knows his treasure, no not you:
He that made Egypt blind, from whence you grew
Scaby and lousy, that the world might see
Your calculations are as blind as ye,
He that made all the stars, you daily read,
And from thence filch a knowledge how to feed;
Hath hid this from you, your conjectures all
Are drunken things, not how, but when they fall;
Man is his own star, and the soul that can
Render an honest, and a perfect man
Command all light, all influence, all fate,
Nothing to him falls early or too late.
Our acts our angels arc, or good or ill,
Our fatal shadows that walk by us still,
And when the stars are labouring, we believe
It is not that they govern, but they grieve
For stubborn ignorance; all things that are
Made for our general uses are at war,
Even we among ourselves, and from the strife
Your first unlike opinions got a life.
O man, thou image of thy makers good,
What canst thou fear, when breathed into thy blood
His spirit is, that built thee? what dull sense
Makes thee suspect, in need, that providence?
Who made the morning, and who placed the light
Guide to thy labours? who called up the night,
And bid her fall upon thee, like sweet showers
In hollow murmurs, to lock up thy powers?
Who gave thee knowledge, who so trusted thee,
To let thee grow so near himself, the tree?
Must he then be distrusted? shall his frame
Discourse with him, why thus, and thus I am?
He made the angels thine, thy fellows all,
Nay even thy servants, when devotions call.
O canst thou be so stupid then, so dim,
To seek a saving influence, and lose him?
Can stars protect thee? or can poverty,
Which is the light to heaven, put out his eye?
He is my star, in him all truth I find,
All influence, all fate, and when my mind
Is furnished with his fullness, my poor story
Shall outlive all their age, and all their glory.
The hand of danger cannot fall amiss,
When I know what, and in whose power it is.
Nor want, the cause of man, shall make me groan,
A holy hermit is a mind alone.
Doth not experience teach us all we can
To work ourselves into a glorious man?
Love's but an exhalation to best eyes
The matter spent, and then the fool's fire dies?
Were I in love, and could that bright star bring
Increase to wealth, honour, and every thing:
Were she as perfect good as we can aim,
The first was so, and yet she lost the game.
My mistress then be knowledge and fair truth;
So I enjoy all beauty and all youth,
And though to time her lights and laws she lends,
She knows no age that to corruption bends.
Friend's promises may lead me to believe,
But he that is his own friend knows to live.
Affliction when i know it is but this,
A deep allay whereby man tougher is
To bear the hammer, and the deeper still,
We still arise more image of his will.
Sickness an humorous cloud twixt us and light,
And death, at longest ▪ but another night.
Man is his own star, and that soul that can
Be honest is the only perfect man.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
